Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Here bigynneth the prolog of this book the which is namede the talis of Cauntur bury in the whiche pro log thautour openly declarith the names of alle the pilgremes there condicioıı̄uns ⁊and there array
Whan that Apprill with his shouris soote
The drought of Marche hath ꝑper/parshid to the roote
And bathed eủer/rey veyne in swich licoure
Of which v̉er/retue / engendrid is the floure
Whan zepherus eke / with his swete breth
Inspirid hath in eủer/rey holt ⁊and hethe
The tendre croppis / ⁊and the yonge sonne
Hath in the Ram / his halff cours I ronne
And smale fowlis make melodie
That slepen al nyght / with open eyghe
So priketh hem nature / in here coragis
That longen folk to gon / on pilgⁱmagis
And Palmeris for to seke strange strondes
To serue halowes couthe / in sondre londes
And specially / from eủer/rey shiris ende
Of Ingelond to Caunturbery thei wende
The holy blisfull mart̉er/re / for to seke
That hem hath holpen / whan thei were seke /
Bifill that on that sesoıı̄un on a day
In Suthwork atte Tabard as I lay
Redy to wende / on my pilgⁱmage
To Caunt̉er/rebury / with ful deuout corage
At night was come / in to that hosterie
Wel . xxixᵗⁱ . in a companye
Of sondry folk / bi auenture I falle
In feloship / ⁊and pilgremes were thei alle
That toward Caunt̉er/rebury wolde ryde
The chambres ⁊and stablis weren wyde
And wel weren eased at the beste
And shortly whan the sonne was to reste
So hadde I spokyn / with hem eủer/reychon
That I was of here feloship anon .
And made forward erly for to ryse
To take oure wey / there as I yow devise
But nertheles while I haue tyme ⁊and space
Or that I ferther in this tale pace
Me thynketh it acoordaıı̄unt to resoıı̄un
To telle yow al the condicioıı̄un
Of ech of hem so as it semed me
And which they were ⁊and of what degre
And eke in what array that thei were inne
And at a knyght than woll I first bigynne
A knyght ther was / ⁊and that a worthi man
That fro the tyme / that he first bigan
To riden owt / he loued chyualrie
Trouth ⁊and honour / fredom ⁊and curtesie
Ful worthi was he / in his lordis werre
And ther to had he riden / no man ferre
As wel in cristendom / as in hethenesse
And eủer/ree honoured / for his worthynesse
At Alisandre he was whan it was wonne
Ful ofte tyme he hadde the bord bigonne
Aboven alle nacōmns in Pruce
In Lectow hadde he reysed ⁊and in Ruce
No cristenman / so ofte of his degre
In Garnade at the sege eke hadde he be
Of Algezire ⁊and riden in Belmarye
At Lyeis was he ⁊and at Satalye
Whan thei were wonne ⁊and in the grete See
At many a noble arme hadde he be
At mortal batailles had he ben Fiftene
And foughten for our feith at Tramessene
In listes thries ⁊and ay slayn his foo
This ilke worthi knyght hadde ben also
Somtyme with the lord of Palatye
Ayeyne another hethen in Turkye
And eủer/ree more he had a soủer/reayne prys
And though that he was worthy he was wys .
And of his port as meke as is a mayde
He neủer/ree yit no vilonye ne saide
In al his liff / vn no mane wight
He was a verry ꝑper/parfit gentill knight
For to tellen yow . of his array
His hors were gode / but he was not gay
Of fustioıı̄un he wered a gepoıı̄un
Al bi smotered with his haburgeoıı̄un
For he was late I come from his viage
And wente for to don / his pilgrimage
With him ther was his sone a yonge Squyere
A loviere ⁊and a lusty bachelere
With lokkes crulle as thei were leyde in presse
Of . xxᵗⁱ . yere of age / he was I gesse
Of his stature he was of evene lengthe
And wonderli delivere ⁊and grete of strengthe .
And he had be somtyme in chyuachie
In Flaundres in Artoys ⁊and Picardie .
And born him wel as of so litill space
In hope to stonden in his lady grace .
Embroyded was he as it were a mede
Al ful of fresshe floures white ⁊and rede
Syngynge he was or floityng al the day
He was as fressh as is the moneth of may
Short was his gowne with slevis longe ⁊and wide
Wel cowde he sitte on an hors ⁊and faire ride
He cowde songes make ⁊and wel endite
Iuste ⁊and eke daunce ⁊and wel portrey ⁊and write
So hote he loued that bi night̉er/re tale
He slepte no more than doth anightyngale
Curteys he was lowly ⁊and suysable
And karff biforn his fader at the table .
A yeman hadde he ⁊and ʆser/siruantes no mo
At that tyme for him liste ride so
And he was clad in coote ⁊and hood of grene
A sheeff of pecok arwes bright ⁊and kene
Vnder his belt he bar ful thrifftyly
Wel couth he dresse his takell yomāmly
His arwes drouped not with fetheris lowe
In his hond he bar a mighti bowe
A not hed hadde he with a broun visage
Of wode craft wel couth he al thusage
Vppon his harme he bar agay bracer
And bi his side a swerde ⁊and a bokeler
And on that other side agay daggere
Harneysed wel ⁊and sharp as poynt of spere
A xpophre on his breste of siluer shene
An horn he bar the bawderike was of grene
A foster was he sothly as I gesse
Ther was also a Nonne a Prioresse
That of hir smylyng was ful symple ⁊and coy
Hir grettest ooth was but bi seint loy
And she was cleped madame Englentyne
Ful wel she songe the ʆser/siruyse dyuine
Entuned in hir nose ful semely
And frenssh she spak ful faire ⁊and fetisly
After the scole of Stratford atte Bowe
For frenssh of Paris was to hir vnknowe
At meete wel I taught was she with alle
She leet no morsell from hir lippes falle
Ne wette hir fyngres in hir savse depe
Wel couth she carye a morsell ⁊and wel kepe
That no droppe ne fil vppon hir breste
In curtesie was sette ful mechel hir leste
Hir oủer/relippe wiped she so clene
That in hir cuppe th̉er/ree was no ferthyng sene
Of grece whan she hadde dronken hir draughte
Ful semely after hir meete she raughte
And sekerly she was of grete disporte
And ful plesaunte ⁊and amyable of porte
And peyned hir to counterfete chere
Of courte / ⁊and to ben estatlich of manere .
And to ben holden digne of reủer/reence
But for to speken of hir conscience
She was so charitable ⁊and pitous
She wolde wepe yiff that she saw amous
Kaught in a trappe if it were ded or bledde
Of smale houndis had she that she fedde
With rosted flessh or mylke or wastelbrede
But soore wept she if oon of hem were dede
Or if men smote it with a yerde smerte
And al was conscience ⁊and tendre herte
Ful semlich hir wympil pynched was
Hir nose was streight hir eyghen grey as glas
Hir mouth ful smal . ⁊and ther to softe ⁊and rede
But sekerly she hadde a faire forhede
It was almost a spanne brood I trowe
For hardly she was nought vndirgrowe
Ful fetis was hir cloke as I was war
A smal coral abowte hir arme she bar
A peire of bedis gavded al with grene
And ther on heng a broch of gold ful shene
On which ther first wreten a crowned A .
And after Amor vincit omnia .
Another Nonne with hir had she
That was hir chapeleyne ⁊and prestes thre .
A Monke ther was a faire for the maistrie
An owtrider that loued venorie
A manly man to ben an abbot able
Ful many a deynte hors hadde he in stable
And whan he rood men myghte his bridel here
Gyngelyng in a whistlyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde as doth the chapel belle
Ther as this lord was keper of the celle
The rewle of seint Mavre / or of seint Benet
Bi cause that it was olde ⁊and somdel streit
This ilke monke leet olde thinges pace
And helde after the newe world the trace
He yaff nought of the text a pulled hen
That seith that hunters ben nought holy men .
Ne that a monke whan he is recheles
Is likned to a fyssh that is waterles
That is to seie amonke owt of his cloystre
But thilke text held he nought worth a noystre
And I seide his opynyon was goode
What shulde he studie / ⁊and make him silff woode
Vppon a book alday in cloystre to poure
Or swynke with his houndes ⁊and laboure
As Austyn bit how shal the world be sued
Lat Austyn haue his swynke to hym reʆser/sirued
Ther fore he was a prikasour a right
Grehoundes he hadde as swifft as foule in flight
Of prikyng ⁊and huntyng for the hare
Was al his luste for no cost wolde he spare
I say his slevis I purfiled at the honde
With grys and that the fyneste in a londe
And for to fastne his hood vndir the chynne
He hadde of gold wrought a ful curious pynne
A love knotte in the grett̉er/re ende ther was
His hed was balled that shon as eny glas
And eke his face as he hadde ben anoynt
He was a lord ful fatt ⁊and in good poynt
His eighen stepe ⁊and rollyng in his hede
That stemed as a forneys of lede
His botis souple his hors in gret estate
Now c̉er/reteīmly he was a faire prelate
He nas nought pale as a forpyned goost
A fatt swan louede he beste of any roost
His palfray was as broun as is a berye
A Frere ther was a wantoun ⁊and a merye
A lymytour a ful solempne man
In al the ordres foure is noon that can
So mechel of Daliaunce ⁊and faire langage
He hadde made ful many a Mariage
Of yonge wōmmen at his owne coost
Vn to his ordre he was a noble poost
Ful wel biloued ⁊and famulier was he
With Frankeleyns oủer/re al in his contre
And with worthi wōmmen of the town
For he hadde power of confessioıı̄un
As seide him selff more than a curat
For of his ordre he was licenciat
Ful swetely herde he confessioıı̄un
And plesaunt was his absolucioıı̄un
He was an esy man to yeff penaunce
Ther as he wiste to haue a good pitaunce
For vn to a poure ordre for to yive
Is signe that a man is wel I shrive
For if he yaff he dorste make auaunt
He wiste that a man was repentaunt
For many a man so hard is of his herte
He may nought wepe al though hīm sore smerte
Therfore in stede of wepyng ⁊and preyeres
Men mote yeve siluer to the poure freres
His tepet was ay farsed ful of knyvis
And pynnes for to yeve to faire wivis
And c̉er/reteinly he hadde a mery note
Wel cowde he syngen ⁊and pleyen on a rote
Of tydyngges bar he witt̉er/reli the pris
His nekke was whight as the floure delys
Ther to he was strong as a champioıı̄un
He knewe the taủer/renes wel in eủer/rey toıı̄un
And eủer/reich hostiller ⁊and tapster
Bet than a lazar or a begger
For vn to swich a worthi man as he
Accorded nought as bi his faculte
To haue with swich sike lazar a queyntaunce
It is nought honest it may not avaunce
For to delen with swich poraille
But al with riche ⁊and sellers of vitaille
And oủer/real ther as ꝓprofit shulde a rise
Curteys he was ⁊and lowly of ʆser/siruyse
Ther nas no man nowher so v̉er/retuous
He was the beste begger in his hous
For though a widewe hadde not a sho
So plesaunt was his In principio
Yit wolde he haue a ferthing or he wente
His purchace was wel bett̉er/re than his rente
And rage he couth right as it were a whelpe
In louedaies ther cowde he mech helpe
For ther he was not lich a cloystrer
With a thredbare cope as a poure scoler
But he was like a maist̉er/re or a pope
Of double worstede was his semy cope
That rounded as a belle out the presse
Somwhat he lipsede for his wantounesse
To make his englissh swete vppon his tonge
And in his har ping / whan that he hadde songe
His eighen twynklede in his hede a right
As don the sterris in the frosty night
This worthi lymitour was called Huberd
A marchaunt ther was with a forked berd
In mottle ⁊and high on hors he satte
Vppon his hede a flaundrissh beuer hatte
His botis clapsid faire ⁊and fetislye
His resoıı̄uns he spak ful solempnelye
Shewyng alwey thencres of his wynnynge
He wolde the see were kept for any thinge
Bitwixe Middelburgh ⁊and Orewelle
Wel coude he in eschaunge sheldes selle
This worthi man / so wel his witt bisette
Ther wiste no whight that he was in dette
So estatly was he of his goủer/renaunce
With his bargeynes ⁊and with his chevisaunce
For soth he was a worthi man with alle
But sothlich to seyn I not how men hīm calle .
A clerke ther was of Oxonford also
That vn to logik hadde longe I go
As lene was his hors as is a rake
And he nas not right fatt I vndir take
But loked holowe ⁊and ther to soburly
Ful thredbare was his oủer/reeste curteby
For he had geten hīm no benefice
Ne was so worldly to haue office
For hīm was lever haue at his beddis hede
. xxᵗⁱ . bookes clad in blak ⁊and rede
Of Aristotle ⁊and his philosophie
Than robes riche or fithel or gay sawtrie
But al be that he was a Philosophre
Yit hadde he but litil gold in cofre
But al that he myghte of his frendes hente
On bookes ⁊and in lernyng he it spente
And besily gan for tho soules praye
Of hem that fonde hīm wher with to scole aye .
Of studie toke he most cure ⁊and hede
Not o word spak he more than was nede
And that was seide / in forme ⁊and reủer/reence
And short ⁊and quyk / ⁊and ful of high sentence
Sownyng in moral v̉er/retue was his speche
And gladly wolde he lerne / ⁊and gladli teche
A sergiant of the lawe war ⁊and wis
That often hadde ben at parvis
That was also ful riche of excellence
Discret he was ⁊and of gret reủer/reence
He semyd swich his wordes weren so wise
Iustice he was ful often in assise
Bi patent ⁊and bi pleyne cōmmissioıı̄un
For his science ⁊and for his high renoıı̄un
Of fees ⁊and robes hadde he many on
So grett̉er/re purchasour was nowher noon
Al was fee symple to hīm in effecte
His purchasing might not ben infecte
Nowher so bisy a man as he ther nas
And yit he semyd besyer than he was
In termes hadde he caas ⁊and domes alle
That from the tyme of kyng william wer falle
Ther to he couth endite ⁊and make a thing
Ther coude no whight pynche at his writyng
And eủer/rey statut couth he pleyne bi roote
He rood but homly in a medle coote
Girt with a seint of silk with barres smale
Of his array telle I no lenger tale
A Frankeleyne was in that companye
Whight was his berde as is the dayissye
Of his complexioıı̄un he was sangwyne
Wel loued he bi the morow a sop in wyne
To liven in delitte eủer/ree was his wone
For he was Epiournes owne sone
That held opynyoıı̄un that pleyne delite
Was v̉er/rereye felicite ꝑper/parfite
An housholder ⁊and that a gret was he
Senyt Iulian he was in his contre
His bred his ale was alweys aft̉er/re one
A bett̉er/re envyned man was nowher none
With oute bakemete was neủer/ree his hous
Of fissh ⁊and flessh ⁊and that so plentivous
It snewed in his hous of mete ⁊and drynke
Of alle deyntethis that men couth thinke
Aft̉er/re the sondry sesoıı̄uns of the yere
So changed he his mete ⁊and his sopere
Ful many a fatt partrich had he mewe
And many a brem ⁊and many a luce in stuwe
Wo was his coke but his sauce were
Poynaıı̄unt ⁊and sharpe ⁊and redy al his gere
His table dormant in his halle alway
Stood redy coủer/reed al the longe day
At sessioıı̄uns ther was lord ⁊and sire
Ful ofte tyme he was knyght of the shire .
An analas ⁊and a gipser al of silke
Heng at his girdel whight as morne mylke
A shreve had he ben ⁊and
Was nowher swich a worthi vauasour
An haburdasshere ⁊and a Carpentere
A Webbe a Dyere ⁊and a Tapecere
And they were clothed alle in oo lyủer/ree
Of a solempne ⁊and a gret frat̉er/renite
Ful fressh ⁊and newe here gere I piked was
Here knyvis nere chaped nought with bras
But al with silủer/ree wrought ful clene ⁊and well
Here girdellis ⁊and here povches eủer/reydell
Wel semed ech of hem a faire burgeys
To sytten in a yeldhalle on a deys
Eủer/reich for the wisdom that he can
Was shaply for to ben an Alderman
For catal hadde thei I nough ⁊and rente
And eke here wives wolde it wel assente
And ellis c̉er/reteyne thei were to blame
It is ful faire to be clepid madame
And gon to vigilies al byfore
And haue a mantel riallich I bore
A Cook thei hadde with hem for the nones
To boille the chikenes with the marie bones
And poudre marchāmnt tart ⁊and galyngale
Wel coude he knowe a draught of londoıı̄un ale
He couth roost ⁊and seth broille ⁊and frye
Maken mortreux ⁊and wel bake a pye
But gret harm was it a thoughte me
That on his shene a mormal hadde he
For blank manger that made he with the beste
A shipman was there wonyng fer bi weste
For ought I woot he was of Dertemouthe
He rood vppon a rouncy as he couthe
In a gowne of faldyng to the kne
A dagger hangynge in a lace hadde he .
Abowte his necke vnder his harm down
The hote somer hadde made his huwe al brown
And c̉er/reteynly he was a good felawe
Ful many a draughte of wyn he hadde drawe
From Burdeux ward while the chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
Iff that he faughte ⁊and hadde the higher honde
Biwat̉er/re he sente hem hom to eủer/rey londe
But of his craft to riken wel his tydes
His stremes ⁊and his daunger him bisides
His herborewe ⁊and his moone ⁊and his lodemanage
Ther nas noon swich from Hulle to Cartage
Hardy he was ⁊and wys to vndertake
With many a tempest had his berd be shake
He knewe alle the havenes as they were
Fro Stotlond to the Cape Defynystere
And eủer/rey Creke in Bretaigne ⁊and in Spayne
His barge clepid was the Mavdeleyne
With vs ther was a doctour of Phisike
In al this world ne was ther noon hīm like
To speke of Phisike ⁊and of Surgerye
For he was grounded in Astronomye
He kept his pacient a ful gret del
In houres bi his magik naturel
Wel couthe he fortune the ascendent
For his ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of eủer/reych maladie
Were it of hoot or colde or moiste or drye
And where engendred ⁊and of what humour
He was a verry ꝑper/parfite practisour
The cause I knowe ⁊and of his harm the rote
Anon he yaff the sike man his bote
Ful redy hadde he his appoticaries
To sende hem drugges ⁊and his lettuaries
For ech of hem made other for to wynne
Here frendship nas not newe to bigynne .
Wel knewe he the olde Escalapius
And discorides ⁊and eke Ruphus
Olde ypocras haly ⁊and Galyen
Serapion Razie ⁊and Avisen
Aueroys Damascien ⁊and Constantyne
Bernard Gatisdene ⁊and Gylbertyne
of his diete mesurable was he
For it was of no suꝑper/parfluyte
But of gret norsshing ⁊and digestible
His studie was but litel in the bible
In sangweyne ⁊and in pers he clad was al
Lyned with taffata ⁊and with sendal
And yit he was but esy of dispence
He kepte that he wan in pestilence
For gold in phisik is a cordial
Therfore he loved gold in special .
A good wiff ther was of be side Bathe
But she was somdel deff ⁊and that was scathe
Of cloth makinge / she hadde swich an haunte
She passed hem of Ipres ⁊and of Gaunte
and in al the parissh wiff was ther noon
That to the offryng to forn hir shulde goon
And if ther ded c̉er/reteyne wroth was she
That she was owte of alle charite
Hire coủer/rechiefs ful fyne were of grounde
I dorste swere they weyeden ten pounde
That on a sonday weren vppon hir hede
Hir hosyn weren of fyne scarlet rede
Ful streyte I tyede ⁊and shoos moiste ⁊and newe
Bolde was hir face ⁊and faire ⁊and rede of hewe
She was a worthi woman al hir lyve
Housbondes at the chirch dore she hadde fyve
Withouten other companye in youthe
But ther of nedith nought to speke as nouthe
And thries hadde she ben at Ierusalem
She hadde passid many a strange strem .
At Rome she hadde ben ⁊and at Boloigne
In Galyce at seint Iame ⁊and at Coloigne
She couth mech on wandryng bi the weye
Gape tothed was she sothly for to seye
Vppon an ambler esily she satte
I wympled wel ⁊and on hir hede an hatte
As brood as is a bokeler or a targe
A foote mantel a bowte hir hepes large .
And on hir feete a peire of spores sharpe
In felowship wel couth she laughe ⁊and carpe
Of remedies of love she knewe ꝑper/par chaunce
For she couth of that arte the colde daunce
A good man ther was of religioıı̄un
And was a poure ꝑper/parson of a town
But rich he was of holy thought ⁊and werk
He was also alerned man ⁊and a clerk
That cristis gospel truly wolde preche
His parisshyns deuoutly wolde he teche
Benigne he was ⁊and wonder diligent
And in adủer/resite ful pacient
And swich he was previd often sithes
Ful loth were him to cursen for his tithes
But rather wolde he yeven oute of doute
Vn to his poure parisshens aboute
Of his offryng ⁊and of his substaunce
He couth in litel thing haue suffisaunce
Wide was his parissh ⁊and houses fer a sondre
But he ne laft nought for rayne ne thondre
In sikenesse nor in myschief to visite
The ferreste in his parisshe meche ⁊and lite
Vppon his feete ⁊and in his honde a staff
This noble ensample to his shepe he yaff
That first he wrought ⁊and aft̉er/re that he taughte
Owte of the gospel he tho wordes kaughte
And this figure he addede eke ther to
That and yif gold ruste what shal Iren do .
For yf a preste be foule on whom we truste
No wonder is a lewde man to ruste
And shame it is if a prest take kepe
A shetyn shepherde ⁊and a clene shepe
Wel ought a preste ensample for to yeve
Bi his clennesse how that his shepe shulde live
He sette naught his bnfice to hire
And laft his shepe a combred in the myre
And ran to london vn to seint Poules
To seke him a chauntrie for soules
Or with a britherhede / to ben witholde
But dwelte at hom ⁊and kepte wel his folde
So that the wolff ne made it not myscarye
He was a shepeherde ⁊and not a mercenarye
And though he holy were ⁊and v̉er/retuous
He was nought to synful men dispitous
Ne of his speche dangerous ne digne
But in his techyng discret ⁊and benigne
To drawen folk to heuen bi fairnesse
Bi good ensample this was his besynesse
But hit were ony ꝑper/parsoıı̄un obstinate
What so he were of high or lowe estate
Him wolde he snebbe sharply for the nones
A bett̉er/re preest I trowe that nowhere non es
He waytede after no pompe ⁊and reủer/reence
Ne maked him no spiced conscience
But cristis lore ⁊and his apostelis twelve
He tawte / but first he folwede it him selve .
With him ther was a plowman was his brother
That hadde I ladde of donge ful many a fother
And a trewe swynker ⁊and a good was he
Livynge in pees ⁊and ꝑper/parfite charite
God loued he beste with al his herte
At alle tymes though he gamede or smerte
And than his neighebore right as him selve
He wolde thresshe ⁊and ther to dike ⁊and delve .
For cristis sake for eủer/rey poure whight
Withoute hire yf it lay in his myght
His tithes paied he ful faire ⁊and wel
Bothen of his propre swynke ⁊and his catel
In a Tabard he rood vppon a Mere
There was also a Reve ⁊and a Millere
A Sompnour ⁊and a Pardoner also
A Maunciple ⁊and my selff ther were no mo
The Millere was a stoute carle for the nones
Ful bigg he was of brawne ⁊and of bones
That preved wel for oủer/real thare he cam
At wrastlyng he wolde haue a wey the Ram
He was short shuldred a thikke knarre
The was no dore but he wolde heve of barre
Or breke it at a rennyng with his hede
His berd as any sowe or fox was reede
And ther to brood as though it were a spade
Vppon the cop right of his nose haade
A werte ⁊and theron stood a tufte of heeris
Rede as the berstelis of a sowes Eris
His nose thrillis blak were ⁊and wide
A swerd ⁊and a bokeler / bar he bi his side
His movthe as gret was / as a fourneys
He was a Iangler ⁊and a goliardeys
And that was most of synne ⁊and of harlotrie
Wel couthe he stele corn ⁊and tolle thrie
And yit he hadde a thombe of gold parde
A whighte coote ⁊and a bliewe hood wered he
Abaggepipe wel couthe blowe ⁊and sown
And therwithal he brought vs owt of town
A gentil Maunciple was there of a temple
Of which a catour myght take ensample
For to ben wise in biyng of vitaylle
For whethir he paiede or toke bi taylle
Algate he wayted so in his a chate
That he was ay aforn ⁊and in good estate
Now is not that of god a ful faire grace
That swich a lewid mannys witte shal pace
The wisdom of an hepe of lernede men
Of maistres hadde he mo than thries ten
That were of lawe expert ⁊and curious
Of which ther were a doseyne in that hous
Worthi to ben Stiwardes of rente ⁊and londe
Of any lord that is in al Ingelonde
To make him live with his ꝓpropre good
In honour detteles but yf that he were wood
Or live as scarsly as him list desire
And able for to helpen al a shire
In any caas that mighte falle or happe
And yit this maunciple sette ther alther cappe .
The Reve was a sclendir colorik man
His berd was shave as nygh as eủer/ree he can
His heer was bi his eeris ful rounde I shorne
His toppe was docked lik a preest bi forne
Ful longe were his legges ⁊and ful lene
I like a staff ther was no calff I sene
Wel couthe he kepe a garner or a bynne
Ther was noon Auditour couthe on him wynne
Wel wiste he bi the droughthe ⁊and bi the reyne
The yeldyng of his seed ⁊and of his greyne
His lordis shepe his nete his dayerie
His swyn his hors his stoor his pulletrie
Was hooly in this reves goủer/renynge
And bi his couenaunt yaff the rikenynge
Syn that his lord was twenty yere of age
Ther couthe noman bringe him in arrerage
Ther nas bailliff ne herde ne other hyne
That he ne knewe his sleight ⁊and his covyne
They were adrad of him as of the deth
His wonynge was ful faire vppon an heth
With grene trees shadewed was his place
He couthe bette than his lord purchace .
Ful riche he was a stored privily
His lord he couth wel plesen subtyly
To yive ⁊and lene him / of his owne good
And haue a thanke ⁊and yit a cote ⁊and hood
In youthe he hadde lerned a good mystere
He was a wel good whrighte a carpenter
This Reve satte vppon a wel good stot
That was pomly grey ⁊and highte scot
A long surcote of peers vppon he hadde
And bi his side he bar a rusty bladde
Of Northfolk was this reve of which I telle
Biside a town men clepen it Bladeswelle
Tukked he was as is a frere a bowte
And eủer/ree he rood the hyndereste of our rowte
A Sompnour was ther with vs in that place
That hadde a firy cherubynnes face
For savseflem he was with eyghen narwe
Als hoote he was ⁊and lecherous as a sparwe
With scalled browes blak ⁊and piled berde
Of his visage children weren a ferde
Ther quyk siluer litarge or bremston
Boras orsure ne oyelle of tartre noon
Ne oynement that wolde clennce ⁊and bite
That him myghte helpe of his whelkes whighte
Nor of the knobbes sittyng in his chekes
Wel loued he garlik oynons ⁊and eke lekes
And for to drinke stronge wyn reede as blood
Than wolde speke ⁊and crie as he were wood .
And whan he hadde wel dronken the wyne
Than wolde he speke no worde but latyne
A fewe t̉er/remes hadde he two or thre
That he hadde lerned owt of som decre
No wonder is he herde it all the day
And ek ye knowen it wel / how that a Iay
Can clepe watte / as wel as can the pope
But ho so couthe in other thing him grope .
Than hadde he spent al his philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wolde he crie
He was agentil harlot ⁊and a kynde
A better felowe shulde no men fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyn
A good felowe to haue his concubyn
A twelf moneth ⁊and excuse him atte fulle
Ful privily ek a fynch couthe he pulle
And yf he founde owher a good felawe
He wolde techyn him to haue noon awe
In swich caas of the Archidekyns curs
But yf mannys soule were in his purs
For in his purs he sholde punysshed be
Purs is the Archideknes helle seide he
But wel I woot he lyhede right in dede
Of cursyng oughte ech gilty man him drede
For curs wol sle right as a soillyng savith
And also war him of a significauith
In daungere hadde he at his owne gyse
The yonge gerles of al the diocise
And knewe here consaille ⁊and what was al her rede
A garland hadde he sette / vppon his hede
As gret as it were for an ale stake
A bokeler hadde he made him of a cake
With him ther rood agentil ꝑper/pardoner
Of Rounvale his frende ⁊and his comper
That streight was comen fro the court of Rome
Ful lowde songe he come hider love to me
This sōmpnour bar to him a stiff burdoıı̄un
Was neủer/ree trompe of halff so gret a sown
This pardoner hadde heere as yolowe as wax
But smowthe it heng as doth a strike of flax
Bi ounces henge his lokkes that he hadde
And therwith he his shildres oủer/respradde
But thynne it lay bi culpons oon ⁊and oon
But hood for iolyte werede he noon .
For it was trussed vp / in his walet
Him thoughte he rood al of the newe get
Discheuele saf his cappe he rood al bare
Swich glaryng eyghen hadde he as an hare
A vernycle hadde he sewid vppon his cappe
His walet biforn him in his lappe
Bret ful of ꝑper/pardoıı̄un comen fro Rome al hoote
A voys he hadde as smal as a goote
No berd hadde he ne neủer/ree shulde haue
As smothe it was as it were late shaue
I trowe he were a geldyng or a mare
But of his crafft fro Berwyke in to ware
Ne was ther swich a nother Pardoner
For in his male he hadde a pelewber
Which that he seide was our lady veylle
He seide he hadde a gobet of the seylle
That seint Peter hadde whan that he wente
Vppon the see til ihu crist him hente
He hadde a croys of latoıı̄un ful of stones
And in a glas he hadde pigges bones
But with these relikes whan that he fonde
A poure ꝑper/parsoıı̄un dwelling vppon londe
Vppon a day he gat him more moneye
Than the ꝑper/parsoıı̄un gat in monethis tweye
And thus with feyned flatryng ⁊and Iapes
He made the ꝑper/parson ⁊and the peple his Apes
But trwly to tellen at the laste
He was in chirche a noble ecciaste
Wel couthe rede a lessoıı̄un or a story
But alderbest he song an offertory
For wel he wiste whan that song was songe
He moste preche ⁊and wel affile his tonge
To wynne seluer as he wel cowde
Ther fore he songe so merily ⁊and lowde
Now haue I tolde yow sothly in a clause
Thestate . the araye the nombre ⁊and eke the cause
Whi that assembled was this companye
In Suthwerk at this gentill hostrie
That highte the Tabard faste bi the belle
But now is tyme to yow for to telle
How that we beren vs that ilke night
Whan we were in that hostrie alight
And aft̉er/re wol I tellen of our viage
And al the remanent of our Pilgrimage
And first I praye yow of your curtecie
That ye ne rette it nought my vilonye
Though that I pleynly speke in this matere
To tellen here wordes ⁊and here chere
Ne though I speke here wordes ꝓpropurly
For this ye knowen as wel as I
Who so shal tellen a tale aft̉er/re a man
He mot reherce as nyghe as eủer/ree he can
Eủer/rey worde yf it be in his charge
Al speke he neủer/ree so rudely ⁊and large
Or elles he mot telle his tale vn trewe
Or feyne thinges or fynde wordes newe
He may nought spare al though he were his brother
He mote also wel seye o worde as a nother
Criste spak hīm silff ful brode in holy writte
And wel ye wot no vilonye is hitte
Eke Plato seith whoso can him reede
The wordes mote be cosyn to the deede
Also I praye yow for yeve it me
Al haue I nought sette folk in here degre
Here in these talis as thei shulde stonde
My witte is short / ye may wel vndir stonde
Greet chere made our host to vs eủer/reychon
And to the soper sette he vs anoon .
And served vs with vitailles at the beste
Strong was the wyn ⁊and wel drynke vs leste
A semly man our oost was with alle
For to ben a marchall in an halle .
A large man hewas with eyghen stepe
A fairer burgeys is noon in chepe
Bold of his spech wys ⁊and wel I taughte
And of manhode him lakked right naughte .
Eke therto he was right a mery man
And aft̉er/re soper pleyen he bigan
And spak of merthe among ⁊and other thinges
Whan that we hadde made our rikenynges
And seide thus / Now lordynges trwely
Ye ben to me welcome right hertely
For bi my trouthe yf that I shal not lye
I saw not this yere so mery a companye
At oones in this herburgh as is now
Fayne wolde I don yow merthe wiste I how
And of a merthe I am right now bi thought
To don yow ease ⁊and it shal coste yow nought
¶ Ye goon to Caunturbury god yow spede
The blisful martir quyte yow your mede
And wel I woot as ye goon bi the weye
Ye shapen yow to talkyn ⁊and to pleye
For truly conforte ne merthe is noon
To riden bi the wey dombe as a stoon .
And therfore wol I makyn yow disporte
As I seide arst ⁊and don yow som conforte
And yf yow like alle bi oon assente
For to stonden at my iugemente
And for to werkyn as I shal yow seye
To morow whan we riden bi the weye
¶ Now bi my fader soule that is ded
But ye be merye I wol lese myn hed
Holde vp youre hondes withoute more speche
Oure counsaille was not longe for to seche
Vs thought it was not worth to make it wys
And graunted him withoute more advys
And bad him sey his verdite as him leste
Lordynges qd he now herkneth for the beste .
But take it nought I praie yow in disdeyne
This is the poynt to speke shorte ⁊and pleyne
That ech of yow to shorte with oure weye
In this viage shal telle talis tweye
To Caunturburyward I mene it so
And homwardes he shal telle other two
Of auentures that whilom haue bifalle
And which of yow that berith him best of alle
That is to seyn that tellith in this caas
Talis of best sentence ⁊and most solaas
Shal haue a soper at our alder coste
Here in this place sittyng bi this poste .
Whan that we comen ageyn fro Caunturbury
And for to make yow the more mery
I wol my silff goodly with yow ride
Right at myn owne coste ⁊and be your gyde
And who so wol my Iuggement with seye
Shal pay al that we spende bi the weye
And yf ye vouchesaf that it be soo
Telle me a noon withouten wordes moo
And I wol erly shape me therfore
This thing was graunted ⁊and our othes swore
With ful glad herte ⁊and praied him also
That he wolde vouchesauff for to do soo .
And that he wolde be oure goủer/renour
And of oure talis Iugge ⁊and reportour .
And sette a soper / at a c̉er/reteyne prys
And we wol rewled ben at his devys
In hygh ⁊and lough ⁊and this bi oon assente
We ben accorded to the Iuggemente
And ther vppon the wyn was fet anoon
We dronken ⁊and to reste wente echoon
Withouten eny lenger tariyng
Amorowe whan the day gan to spryng .
Vp roos oure oste ⁊and was oure alder cok
And gaderede vs to gyder in a flok .
And forthe we riden a litil more than paas
Vn to the wateryng of seynt Thomas .
And there our hoste gan his hors areste
And seide lordes herkneth yf yow leste
Ye woot youre forward ⁊and I it wol recorde
Yif euvensong ⁊and morowsong accorde .
Lat se now who shal telle the firste tale
As eủer/ree mot y drynke wyn or ale
Who so be rebell to my Iuggement
Shal paie for al that bi the weye is spent .
Now drawith Cutte or that we ferther twynne
Which hath the shorteste shal begynne .
Sir knyght qd he my maister ⁊and my lorde
Now drawith Cut for that is myn accorde
Cometh nere qd he my lady prioresse
And ye sir clerke lat be your shamestfastnesse
Ne studieth nought lay honde to eủer/rey man
Anoon to drawe eủer/rey whight bigan
And shortly for to tellen as it was
Were it bi auenture or sorte or cas
The soth is this the cut fel to the knyght
Of which ful blithe ⁊and glad was eủer/rey whight
And tellen he moste his tale as it was resoıı̄un
Bi forward ⁊and by composicioıı̄un
As ye han herde what nedith wordes moo
And whan this good man saw that it was soo .
As he that wys was ⁊and obedient
To kepen his forward bi his fre assent
He seide sitthen I shal bigynne the game
What welcome be the cut a goddes name
Now lat vs ride ⁊and herneth what I seie
And with that word we reden forth our weie
And he bigan with right a mery chere
His tale anoon ⁊and seide as ye may here .
Here endith the prolog of this book
(base) And next folwith the knyghtis tale of Arcyte ⁊and Palamon

div.l: (base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay

div.l: (base) Of a Clarree / maad of certeyn wyn

(base) May / with alle thy floures / and thy grene

div.l: (base) How longe Iuno / thurgh thy crueltee
(base) Woltow werreyen / Thebes the Citee
(base) Allas / ybroght is to confusioun
(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun
(base) ¶ Of Cadmus / which that was the firste man
(base) That Thebes bulte / and first bigan
(base) And of the Citee / first was crowned kyng
(base) Of his lynage am I / and his of spryng
(base) By verray ligne / as of the stok roial

(base) I serue hym / as his Squyer pourely

(base) ¶ Allas thow felle Mars / allas Iuno

(base) Saue oonly me / and wrecched Palamoun

(base) ¶ And oueral this / to sleen me outrely
(base) Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly

(base) Ye sleen me with youre eyen / Emelye

(base) And with that word / he fil down in a traunce

(base) ¶ This Palamoun / that thoughte / that thurgh his herte
(base) He felte a coold swerd / sodeynly glyde

div.l: (base) He stirte hym vp / out of the buskes thikke

(base) Now art thow hent that louest my lady so
(base) For whom that I haue / al this peyne and wo
(base) And art my blood / and to my conseil sworn
(base) As I ful ofte / haue toold thee her biforn
(base) And hast byiaped here / duc Theseus
(base) And falsly / chaunged hast thy name thus
(base) I wol be deed / or ellis thow shalt dye
(base) Thow shalt noght / loue my lady Emelye
(base) But I wol loue hire oonly / and namo
(base) For I am Palamon / thy mortal foo
(base) And thogh that I / no wepne haue in this place

(base) I drede noght that outher thow shalt dye

(base) ¶ This Arcite / with ful despitous herte

(base) As fiers as leoun / pulled out his swerd

(base) Haue here my trouthe / tomorwe I nyl nat faille
(base) Withouten wityng of any oother wight
(base) That here I wol be founden / as a knyght

(base) ¶ O Cupide / out of alle charitee

(base) Thou myghtest wene / that this Palamoun

(base) ¶ This mene I now / by myghty Theseus

(base) ¶ Cleer was the day / as I haue told er this

div.l: (base) And wolde haue kist his feet ther as he stood

(base) And thogh he first. for Ire quook and sterte

div.l: (base) And that hir deeth / lyth in my myght also

div.l: (base) Ech of yow bothe / is worthy doutelees
(base) To wedden whan tyme is / but nathelees
(base) I speke / as for my suster Emelye
(base) For whom / ye haue this stryf and Ialousye
(base) Ye woot your self. she may nat wedden two
(base) Atones / thogh ye fighten eueremo
(base) That oon of yow / al be hym looth / or lief
(base) He moot go pipen / in an yuy leef
(base) This is to seyn / she may nat now haue bothe
(base) Al be ye neuere so Ialous / ne so wrothe
(base) And for thy / I yow putte in this degree
(base) That ech of yow / shal haue his destynee
(base) As hym is shape / and herkneth in what wyse
(base) Lo here youre ende / of that I shal deuyse
(base) ¶ My wil is this / for plat conclusioun
(base) Withouten any replicacioun
(base) If that yow liketh / take it for the beste
(base) That euerich of yow / shal goon where hym leste
(base) Frely / withouten raunsoun / or daunger
(base) And this day fifty wykes / fer ne neer
(base) Euerich of yow / shal brynge an hundred knyghtes
(base) Armed for listes / vp at alle rightes
(base) Al redy / to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) And this bihoote I yow / withouten faille
(base) Vpon my trouthe / and as I am a knyght
(base) That wheither of yow bothe / that hath myght
(base) This is to seyn / that wheither he or thou
(base) May with his hundred / as I spak of now
(base) Sleen his contrarie / or out of lystes dryue
(base) Thanne shal I yeue / Emelye to wyue
(base) To whom that Fortune / yeueth so fair a grace
(base) The lystes / shal I maken in this place
(base) And god so wisly / on my soule rewe
(base) As I shal / euene Iuge been and trewe
(base) Ye shul noon oother ende / with me maken
(base) That oon of yow / ne shal be deed / or taken
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And if yow thynketh / this is wel ysayd
(base) Sey youre auys / and holdeth yow apayd
(base) This is youre ende / and youre conclusioun
(base) ¶ Who looketh lightly now / but Palamoun
(base) Who spryngeth vp for ioye / but Arcite
(base) Who koude telle / or who koude it endite
(base) The ioye / that is maked in the place
(base) Whan Theseus / hath doon so fair a grace
(base) But doun on knees / wente euery maner wight
(base) And thonken hym / with al hir herte and myght
(base) And namely the Thebans ofte sythe
(base) And thus with good hope / and herte blythe
(base) They take hir leeue / and homward gonne they ryde
(base) To Thebes / with olde walles wyde
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars
(base) ¶ Incipit pars secunda
(base) The ordinaunce of lystys that Thesyus ordeynyd ⁊and cᵒ
(base) I trowe / men wolde deme it necligence
(base) If I foryete / to tellen the despence
(base) Of Theseus / that gooth so bisily
(base) To maken vp the lystes / roially
(base) That swich a noble Theatre / as it was
(base) I dar wel seyn / in this world ther nas
(base) The circuit a myle was aboute
(base) Walled of stoon / and dyched al withoute
(base) Round was the shap / in manere of compas
(base) Ful of degrees / the heighte of sixty paas
(base) That whan a man / was set on o degree
(base) He letted noght his felawe for to see
(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit
(base) And shortly to concluden / swich a place
(base) Was noon in erthe / as in so lite a space
(base) For in the lond / ther was no crafty man
(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
(base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages
(base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse
(base) And for to doon / his ryte and sacrifise
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) He Estward hath / vpon the gate aboue
(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue
(base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie
(base) And on the westward / in memorie
(base) Of Mars / he maked hath right swich another
(base) That coste largely / of gold a fother
(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral
(base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
(base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
(base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren
(base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland
(base) And a Cokkow / sittyng on hir hand
(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces
(base) Of loue / whiche that I rekned / and rekne shal
(base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
(base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
(base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye
(base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
(base) Suffiseth heere ensamples / oon or two
(base) And though / I koude rekne a thousand mo
(base) ¶ The statue of Venus / glorious for to see
(base) Was naked / fletyng in the large See
(base) And fro the nauele doun / al couered was
(base) With wawes grene / and brighte as any glas
(base) A Citole in hir right hand / hadde she
(base) And on hir heed / ful semely for to se
(base) A rose gerland / fressh / and wel smellynge
(base) Aboue hir heed / hir dowues flikerynge
(base) Biforn hire stood / hir sone Cupido
(base) Vpon his shuldres / wynges hadde he two
(base) And blynd he was / as it is ofte seen
(base) A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and keene
(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
(base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere

div.l: (base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren

(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye

(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown

(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge

(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue

div.l: (base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde

(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne

div.l: (base) Ne noman so hardy this ordenaunce forto breke

div.l: (base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two

Suffising right I now / as for a day
But ar that he hadde / made al this aray
He sente his knave / ⁊and eke his wenche also
Vppon his nede to Londoıı̄un / for to go
¶ And on the monday / whan it drough to night
He shette his dore / withoute candel light ¶
And dressid al thing / as it sholde be
And shortly clomben vp alle thre
Thei setten stille / wel a forlong way
Now pater noster clum / seide Nicholay
And clum qd Iohn / ⁊and clum seide Alisoıı̄un
This Carpenter / seide his deuocioıı̄un
And stille he sitte ⁊and biddith his prayere
A waityng on the rayne / if he it hiere
The deth slepe / for wery besynesse
Fil on this Carpent̉er/re / right as I gesse
A boute corfew tyme / or litel more
For travaille of his gost / he groneth sore
And efte he routeth / for his hed myslay
Doun bi the laddre / stalketh Nicholay
And Alisoıı̄un ful softe / a doun she spedde
Withouten wordes mo / thei goıı̄un to bedde
There as the Carpenter / is wonte to lye
There was the reuel / ⁊and the melodie
And thus lith Alisoıı̄un / ⁊and Nicholas
In besynesse / or merthe / ⁊and in solas
Til that the belle / of laudes gan to rynge
And freris in the chauncell gonne synge .
¶ This parisshe clerc / this amorous Absoloıı̄un
That is for loue alwey / so wo bigoıı̄un
Vppon the monday / was at Oseney
With compaigne / him to disport ⁊and pley
And axede vppon cas / a cloistrer
Ful privily / after Iohn the Carpenter
And he drough him aparte / out of the chirche
And seide I not / I saugh him here not wirche
Sithe Saturday I trowe that he be wente
For tymber / there oure Abbot hath him sente
For he is wont / for tymber for to go
And duellyn at the graunge / a day or two
Or ellis he is / at his hous c̉er/reteyne
Where that he is / I can not sothly seyne ¶
This Absoloıı̄un ful ioly was / ⁊and light
And thoughte now is tyme / to wake alnight
For sekerly / I saw him not sterynge
Abouten his dore / syn day bigan to sprynge
So moty thrive / I shal at cokkes crowe
Ful privily knokken / at his wyndowe
That stant ful lowe / vppon his bowres walle
To Alison now wol I / tellen alle
My loue longyng / for yit I shal not mysse
That at the leste wey / I shal hir kysse
Som maner comforte / shal I haue parfay
My mouth hath icched / al this longe day
That is a signe / of kissyng at the leeste
Alnight me met eke / I was at a feeste
Therfore I wol go slepe / an houre or twey
And al the night / than wol I wake ⁊and pley
Whan that the first cokke / hath crowe a noon
Vp rist this ioly louer Absoloıı̄un
And him arayeth gay / at poynt devise
But first he chewith grayn ⁊and likorise
To smellen swete / ar he hadde kempt his heere
Vnder his tonge / a trewe loue he bere
For therby wende he / to be gracious
He rowmeth to the Carpenteris hous
And stille he stant / vnder the shotwyndowe
Vn to his breste it raught / it was so lowe
And softe he coughed / with a semy sown
What do ye hony combe / swete Alisoıı̄un
My faire brid / my swete synamome
A wake lemman myn / ⁊and spekith to me
Wel litil thenke ye / vppon my wo
That for youre loue I sweete there I go
No wonder is though that I swelte ⁊and swete
I morne as doth a lambe / after the tete
I wis lemman / I haue swiche loue longyng
That like a turtil trewe / is my mornyng . ¶
I may not eten / no more than a mayde
Go fro the wyndowe Iakke foole she sayde
As helpe me god / it wol not be combame
I loue another / ⁊and ellis I were to blame
Wel bet than the / bi Ihıı̄un Absolon
Go forth thi wey or I wil caste a ston
And lete me slepe / a twenty deuel way
Allas qd Absoloıı̄un / ⁊and wayllaway
That trewe loue / was eủer/ree so yuel bisette
Than kisse me / syn it may be no bette
For Ihus loue / ⁊and for the loue of me
Woltow than go thi way / therwith qd she
Ye c̉er/retes lemman / qd this Absoloıı̄un
Than make the redy qd she / I come anoon
And vnto Nicholas she seide stille
Now hust / ⁊and thow shalt laugh thi fille .
This Absoloıı̄un doun sette him / on his knees
And saide I am a lord / at alle degrees
For after this I hope / ther cometh more
Lemman thi grace ⁊and swete brid thin ore
The wyndow she vndoth / ⁊and that in haste
Haue do quod she com of ⁊and spede the faste
Lest that oure neghbores / the espie
This Absolon gan wipe his mouthe / ful drye
Derke was the night / as picche or as the cole
And at the wyndowe out / she putte hir hole
And Absolon him fil / no bet ne wers
But with his mouthe / he keste hir naked ers
Ful sauourly / or he were war of this
Abak he sterte / ⁊and thoughte it was amys
For wel he wyste / a woman hath no bered
He felt a thing al rough / ⁊and longe I hered
And seide fy allas what haue I do
Tehe quod she / ⁊and clapt the wyndowe to
And Absolon goth forth / a sory paas
A berde a berde / seide hendy Nicholas
By godis corpus / this goth faire ⁊and wel
This sely Absoloıı̄un herde it eủer/reydel ¶
And on his lippis he gan for angur bite
And to him selff he seide / I shal the quyte
Who rubbeth now / who froteth now his lippes
With dust / with sonde / with strawe / with cloth / with chippes
But Absoloıı̄un / that seith ful ofte allas
My soule bi take I / vn to Satanas
But me were leuer / than al this toun qd he
Of this dispite a wreken for to be
Allas qd he allas / I ne hadde I bleynt
His hote loue is cold / ⁊and al I queynt
For fro that tyme / that he had kest hir ers
Of paramours / he sette nought a kers
¶ For he was heled / of his maladie
Ful ofte ꝑper/paramours / he gan diffie
And wepe as doth a child / that is I bete
A softe paas / he wente oủer/ree the strete
Vn to a smyth / men called Daun Geruays
That in his forge / smethith / plough harnays
He sharpith share / ⁊and cultour besily
This Absoloıı̄un knokketh / al esily
And seide vn do Geruays / ⁊and that anoon
What who artow / it am I Absolon
What Absolon / what cristes swete tree
Whi rise ye so rathe / ey benedicite
What eyleth yow / som gay gerle god it woot
Hath brought yow thus / on the viritoot
Bi seynt note ye wot wel what I meene
This Absoloıı̄un ne rought not a beene
Of al his pley / no worde ageyn he gaff
He had more tow / on his distaff
Than Geruays knewe / ⁊and seide frende so dere
The hote cultour in the chemeney here
As lene it me I haue therwith to done
I wol bringe it ageyn / to the ful sone
Geruays answerde / c̉er/retes were it golde
Or in a poke nobles / alle vntolde ¶
Thow shuldist haue it / as I am trewe smyth
Ey cristes foo / what wil ye do ther with
Ther of qd Absolon / be as be may
I shal wel tellen it the / to morow or day
And caughte the cultour / bi the colde stele
Ful softe out at the dore / he gan stele
And wente vn to the Carpent̉er/reis wal
He koughede first / ⁊and knokkede therwithal
Vppon the wyndowe / right as he dede ere
This Alison answerde / who is there
That knokketh so / I warante it a theff
Whi nay qd he / god woot my swete leff
I am thin Absolon / thi derelyng
Of gold qd he / I haue the brought aryng
My moder yaff it me / so god me save
Ful fyn it is / ⁊and therto wel I grave
This wol I yeven the / if thow me kisse
This Nicholas was risen / for to pisse
And thoughte he wolde / amenden al the iape
He shulde kisse his ers / or that he scape
And vp the wyndowe / dide he hastily
And owte his ers / he putte privily
Ouer the buttok / to the haunche boıı̄un
And therwith spak this clerc / this Absoloıı̄un
Speke swete brid / I not where thow art
This Nicholas anoon / leete fle a fart
As grete as it had ben / a thonder dente
That with the stroke / he was almost I blente
And he was redy / with his yren hoot
And Nicholas / in the ers he smoot
Of goth the skyn / an handbrede abovte
The hoote cultour / brend so his tovte
And for the smerte / he wende for to dye
As he were wood / for woo he gan to crye
Helpe water water / helpe for godus herte
This Carpenter / out of his slomber sterte ¶
And herde oon cryen water / as he were wood
And thought allas / now cometh Noyes flood
And sette him vp / withoute wordes mo
And with an ax / he smoot the corde atwo
And doun goth al / he founde neither to seille
No bred nor ale til he com to the selle
Vppon the flore / ⁊and there a swoıı̄un he lay
Vp sterte Alison / ⁊and hende Nicholay
And criden out / ⁊and harow / in the strete
The neighbores / both smale ⁊and grete
In ronnen / for to gavren on this man
That a swown lay / both pale ⁊and wan
¶ For with that fall / he brosten hath his arme
But stonden he moste / to his owne harme
For whan he spak / he was anoon bore down
With hende Nicholas / ⁊and Alisoıı̄un
Thei tolde eủer/rey man / that he was wood
He was so agast / of Noyes flood
Thorurgh fantasie / that of his vanyte
He hadde bought him / knedyng tubbes thre
And hadde hem hanged / in the roff above
And that he praide hem / for godis loue
To sitten in the roff / ꝑper/par companye
The folk gan laughwen / at his fantasie
And to the roff thei kyken / ⁊and thei gape
And torned al his harm / vn to a Iape
For what so eủer/re this Carpenter answerde
It was for nought / no man his resoıı̄un herde
With othes grete / he was so sworn adown
That he was holden wood / in al the town
For eủer/rey clerc anonright / helde with other
Thei seide the man is wood / my leue brother
And eủer/rey wight gan laughwen / at this striff
Thus swives was / the Carpenters wiff
For al his kepyng / ⁊and his ialousie
And Absoloıı̄un hath kest / hir nether eighe ¶
And Nicholas is scalded in his tovte
This tale is don / ⁊and god saue al the route .
Here endith the miller his tale of Absolon and hende Nicholas

(base) That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
(base) To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
(base) For she is fairer as they demen alle
(base) Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
(base) And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
(base) And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
(base) Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
(base) That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
(base) Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
(base) And more plesaunce for her high lynage
(base) Hir brother was soo faire of his age
(base) That him to seeene the peple had caught plesaunce
(base) Commmendinge nowe the marques gouernaunce
(base) O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
(base) Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
(base) Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
(base) Here may ye se the peple how newe
(base) For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
(base) Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
(base) And changeable be right as the mane
(base) Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
(base) A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
(base) Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee

div.l: (base) Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
(base) For they were glad right for the noueltee
(base) To han a newe lady of hir town
(base) Namoore of this make I now mencioun
(base) But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
(base) And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
(base) Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
(base) That to the feste was apertinent
(base) Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
(base) Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
(base) But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
(base) With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
(base) And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
(base) With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
(base) And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
(base) That no defaute no man aparceyueth
(base) But ay they wondren what she myghte be
(base) That in so poure array was for to se
(base) And koude swich honour and reuerence
(base) And worthily they preysen hir prudence
(base) In al this mene while she ne stente
(base) This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
(base) With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
(base) So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
(base) But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
(base) To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
(base) Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
(base) Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
(base) How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
(base) Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
(base) A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
(base) I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
(base) And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
(base) Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
(base) O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
(base) That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
