div.l: (base) This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
(base) For she is fostred in hir norissynge
(base) Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
(base) She koude nat aduersitee endure
(base) As koude a poure fostred creature
(base) And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
(base) Hir glad cheere and no malice at al
(base) And he so ofte had doon to hir offence
(base) And she ay sad and constant as a wal
(base) Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
(base) With pacience Grisild he quiteth
(base) This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
(base) To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
(base) This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
(base) Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
(base) I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
(base) Mankynde which that he wroght
(base) As wel as euere womman was assayed
(base) In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
(base) Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
(base) And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
(base) And she for wonder took of it no keep
(base) She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
(base) She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
(base) Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
(base) Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
(base) Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
(base) Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
(base) Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
(base) This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
(base) To be my wyf that oother feithfully
(base) Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
(base) Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
(base) At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
(base) Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
(base) That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
(base) And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
(base) I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
(base) For no malice ne for no crueltee

div.l: (base) But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
(base) And nat to sleen my children god forbede
(base) But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
(base) Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
(base) Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
(base) For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
(base) She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
(base) And in hir armes pitously wepynge
(base) Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
(base) Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
(base) She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
(base) O which a pitous thyng it was to se
(base) O such a pitous þing it was to see
(base) Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
(base) Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
(base) That ye han saued me my children deere
(base) Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
(base) Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
(base) No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
(base) O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
(base) Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
(base) That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
(base) Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
(base) And youre benygne fader tendrely
(base) Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
(base) Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
(base) And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
(base) Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
(base) That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
(base) The children from hir arm they gonne arace
(base) O many a teer o many a pitous face
(base) Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
(base) Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
(base) Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
(base) She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
(base) And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
(base) Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce

div.l: (base) Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
(base) That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
(base) Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
(base) Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
(base) Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
(base) And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
(base) And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
(base) With a coroune of many a riche stoon
(base) Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
(base) And ther she was honured as hir oghte
(base) Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
(base) For euery man and womman dooth his myght
(base) This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
(base) Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
(base) For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
(base) This feste was and gretter of costage
(base) Than was the reuel of hir mariage
(base) Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
(base) Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
(base) And richely his doghter maried he
(base) Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
(base) Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
(base) His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
(base) Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
(base) His sone succedeth in his heritage
(base) In reste and pees after his fader day
(base) And fortunat was eek his mariage
(base) Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
(base) This world is nat so strong it is no nay
(base) As it hath been in olde tymes yore
(base) And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
(base) This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
(base) Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
(base) For it were inportable thogh they wolde
(base) But for that euery wight in his degree
(base) Sholde be constant in aduersitee
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
(base) With pacience he Grisilde aquiteth
(base) This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
(base) For sith a womman was so pacient
(base) Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
(base) Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
(base) For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
(base) But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
(base) As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
(base) He preueth folk al day it is no drede
(base) And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
(base) With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
(base) Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
(base) Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
(base) Er we were born knew al oure freletee
(base) And for oure beste is al his gouernance
(base) Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
(base) But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
(base) It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
(base) In al a town Grisildis thre or two
(base) For if that they were put to swiche assayes
(base) The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
(base) With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
(base) It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
(base) For which heere for the wyues loue of Bathe
(base) Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene
(base) In heigh maistrie or ellis were it scathe
(base) I wol with lusty herte fressh and grene
(base) Seye yow a song to glade yow I wene
(base) And lat vs stynte of ernestful matere
(base) Herkneth my song that seith in this manere
(base) Here is ended the tale of the clerk of Oxenford
Grisilde is dede / ⁊and eke hir pacience
And both atonys buried / in Itail
For which I crye / in open audience
No wedded man so hardy be / to a sail
His wivis pacience / in truste to fynde
Grisildis / for in c̉er/reteyne he shal fail . ¶
O noble wivis ful of highe prudence
Lat noon humilite / youre tongis nail
Ne lat no clerkis haue cause / ne diligence
To write of yow a story / of such mervail
As of Grisildis paciente / ⁊and kynde
Lest Chichevache yow swalowe / in hir entrail .
Folwith Ecco / that holdith no scilence
But eủer/ree answerith / in the contirtail
Beth nat bidaffid / for youre innocence
But sharply take on yow / the goủer/renail
Enpoynteth wel this lessoıı̄un / in youre mynde
For comune ꝓprofit / sith hit may avail .
And ye Archiwivis / stondith at defence
Syn ye be stronge / as is a grete Camail
Ne suffrith not / that men do yow offence
And slender wivis / as feble in batail
Beith egre as a Tigre / bi yende the se fer in ynde
Ay clappith as a mylle / I yow consail .
Ne dredith hem nought / doith hem no reủer/reence
For though thyn housbond armed be / in mail
The wordis of thi crabbed eloquence
Shal perssh his breste / ⁊and eke his auentail
In gelousie I rede eke / thow him bynde
And thow shalt make him covche / as a quail .
Yf thow be feyre / there folk ben in psence
Shewe thow thi visage / ⁊and thin apparail
Yf thow be foule / be fre of thi dispence
To gete the frendis / ay do thi travail
Be eủer/re of chere as light / as leff on lynde
And lete hem care . wepe / wrynge ⁊and wail .
Hre endith the Clerke of Oxenford his tale / and next aft̉er/re thost spake
This worthi clerke / whan endid was his tale
Oure oste seide / ⁊and swore by Cokkis bonys
Me were lever / than a barel of ale
My wiff at hom / had herde this legende onys ¶
This is a gentil tale / for the nonys
As to my purpos / wist ye my wil
But thing that wol not be / let hit be stil .
Here bigynneth the wiff of Bathe hir ꝓprolog .
Experience though noon autorite
were in this world / is right I nough for me
to speke of wo / that is in mariage
but lordingis syn I / xij. wynt̉er/re was of age
thanked be god / that is et̉er/rene on live
housbondis at chirche dore / haue I had five
and I so often / haue wedded be
and alle were worthi men / in there degre
but me was tolde / that longe ago nys
that criste ne wente / neủer/ree but onys
to wedding / in the Cane / of Galyle
that bi the same ensample / taughte he me
that I ne weddid shulde be / but onys
lo herken which a sharp worde / for the nonys
be side awelle / Jhıı̄uns god ⁊and man
spak in repref / of the Samaritan
thow hast had .v. housbondis qd he
and that ilke whiche now hath the
is not thin housbond / thus he seide c̉er/reteyne
what he ment therby / I can not seyne
but that I aske / whi the .v. man
was not housbond / to the Samaritan
how many myghte she haue / in mariage
that herde I neủer/ree telle / in myn age
of this nombre / definicioun
men mowe demen ⁊and glosen / vp ⁊and doun
but wel I woot expresse / withouten lye
god bad vs wex / ⁊and multiplye
that gentil texte / can I wel vnderstonde
for wel I woot / that myn housbonde
sholde lete fader ⁊and moder / ⁊and take to me
but of nombre / no mensioıı̄un made he
of bigamye / or of octogamye
whi shulde men speke of hit vilonye
lo here the wise kyng Salamon
I trowe he had wivis mo than oon
as wolde god / hit lefful were to me
to ben refresshed / half so ofte as he
which a yift of god had he / for al his wivis
noman hath such / that now on live is
god woot this noble kyng / vn to my witte
the first night / had many a mery fitte .
with eche of hem / so wel was him on live
blissed be god / for I haue had five
of which I haue piked out the beste
both of here nether purs / ⁊and of here cheste
diủer/res skolis / makith sotil clerkis
and diủer/res practik / in many sondry werkis
makith the parfectour / man to be sekerly
of five housbondis skoling / am I
wel com the sixte / whan that eủer/ree he shal
I wol him not for sake / nothing at al
whan myn housbonde / is fro the world I goon
som cristen man / shal wedde me anoon
for the Appostil seith / that I am fre
to wedde a godishalff / where hit liketh me
he seith to be wedded / is no synne
bett is to be wedded / than to blynne
what recke me / though men sey wellaweye
of shrewed Lameth / ⁊and of his bigameye
I woot Abraham was / aful holy man
and eke Iacob / as fer as hiryn I can
and eche of them / had mo wivis than two
and many a nother man / hath had also
¶ where can ye sey / in eny maner age
that eủer/ree god / defended mariage
by expresse wordis / I pray yow tellith me
or where commaunded he / eủer/ree virginite
I woot as wel as ye hit is no drede
the Appostil whan he spekith of maydenhede
he seith therof pcept haue I noon
men may consail a woman to be oon
but consail is no maner commaundement
he puttith hit / in oure owne Iugement
for had god comnaunded maydenhede
than had he dampned /wedding withouten drede
and certis if ther were no seede I sowe
virginite what shulde therof than growe
Paule dorst nought / commaunde at the leste
a thing of which his maist̉er/re / yaf non heste
the darte is sette vp / of virginite
cacche whos may / who renneth best lat se
but this worde is not take / of eủer/rey wight .
but there as god wol yeve hit / of his myght
I woot wel the Appostil was a mayde
but natheles though he spake ⁊and sayde
he wolde that eủer/rey wight / were as he
al nys but consail / to virginite
and for to be a wiff / he yaff me leve
of indulgence / so hit is not to repve
to wedde me / if that my make dye
withouten excepcioıı̄un / of bigamye
al were hit good / no woman for to tovche
he ment in his bed / or in his covche
for ꝑper/parel hit is / fire ⁊and towe to assemble
ye knowe what this ensample / may resemble
this al ⁊and som / he helde virginite
more parfite than wedding / in freylte
freylte clepe I / but if he or she
wolde leden here liff / in chastite
I graunte hit wel / I haue noon envie
though maydenhede / pferre bigamye
hit liketh hem to be clene / in body ⁊and goste
of myn estate / I wol make no boste .
Ful wel I knowe / a lord in his housolde
hath not eủer/rey vessel of golde
some ben of tre ⁊and do here lord suice
god clepith to him folk / in sondry wise
and eủer/reych hath of god / a ꝓpropir yifte
some this some that / as him list to shifte
virginite is a grete ꝑper/parfeccioun
and contynence eke / with deuocioıı̄unn
but criste that is of ꝑper/parfeccoıı̄un the welle
bad not eủer/rey wight / he sholde go selle
al that he had / ⁊and yeve hit to the pore
and in such wise / folwe him ⁊and his lore
he spak to hem / that wolde leve ꝑper/parfitly
and lordingis bi your leeve / that am not I
I wol be stowe the flour / of al myn age
in the actis ⁊and the fruyte / of mariage
¶ Tel me also / to what conclusioıı̄un
weere membris made / of genacoıı̄un
and in so ꝑper/parfite wise / and why I wroughte
trust right wel / they were not made for noughte
glose who so wol / ⁊and serch both vp ⁊and doun
that they were made / for purgacioun
of vryne / ⁊and other thingis smale
and eke to knowe / a female / from a male
and for noon other cause / sey ye no
the exꝑper/parience woot wel / hit is not so
so that ye clerkis / be not with me wrothe
I sey thus / that they ben made for bothe
that is to sey / for office / ⁊and for ease
of engendrure / there we not god displease
whi shulde men ellis / in here bookes sette
that man shulde yelde / to his wiff hir dette
now wherwith shulde he / make his payment
yf he ne vsede / his sely instrument
than were they made / vppon a creature
to purgen vryne / ⁊and eke to engendrure
but I sey not / that eủer/rey wight is holde
that hath such harneys / as I yow tolde
to gon ⁊and vsen hem / in engendrure
than shulde men take of chastite / no cure
crist was a maide / ⁊and shapen as a man
and many an holy seynt sithe the world bigan
yit lived they eủer/ree / in ꝑper/parfite chastite
I ne wol envie / no virginite
lete hem with brede of pured whete be fedde
and lete vs wivis / ete barly brede
and yit with barly brede Mark telle can
our Lorde Ihu refresshed / many a man
in suche estate as god hath cleped vs
I wol ꝑper/parceiver / I am nought pcious
in wiffhode wol I vse myn instrument
as frely as my maker / hath hit sent
yiff I be dangerous / god yeve me sorowe
myn housbonde shal it haue both eve ⁊and amorowe
whan that him list / com forth ⁊and pay his dette
an housbonde wol I haue / I wol not lette
which shal be / both my dettour ⁊and my thral
And han his tribulacioıı̄un with al
vppon his flesshe / while that I am his wiff
I haue the power / durynge al my liff
vppon his propre body / ⁊and not he
right thus the Appostel / tolde vn to me
and bad our housbondes / for to love vs wel
al this sentence / me liketh eủer/reydel
Uppe sterte the pardoner / ⁊and that anoon
now dame qd he / bi god ⁊and bi seint Iohn
ye ben a noble prechour / in this caas
I was abovte to wedde a wiff allaas
what shulde I bye it / on my flesshe so dere
yit had I lever wedde noon to yere
abyde qd she my tale is not bigonne
nay thow shalt drynken / of another tonne
or that I go / shal sauour wers than ale
and whan I haue tolde forth my tale
of tribulacioıı̄un that is in mariage
of which I am expert / in myn age
this is to seie / my silff hath ben the whippe
than maistow chese / whether thow wilt sippe
of thilke tonne / that I shal abroche
be war of hit / or thow to nygh approche
for I shal telle ensamples / mo than ten
who so that wil not / be war bi other men
by him shulle other men corrected be
these same wordis writeth Protholome
rede in his Almageste / ⁊and take it there
dame I wol pray yow / if your wille were
seide this Pardoner / as ye bigan
telle forth your tale spare for no man
and teche vs yongemen / of your practike
gladly qd she / sith it may yow like
but that I pray / to al this companye
if that I speke / after my fantesie
as taketh nought agreff / of that I seye
for myn entente / is not but for to pleye ;
Now sirs than shal I telle yow my tale
as eủer/ree moty drynke wyn or ale
I shal sey soth / tho housbondes that I hadde
as thre of hem were goode / ⁊and two were badde
the thre were goode men / riche ⁊and olde
vnneth myghten thei / the statute holde
in which thei were bounden vn to me
ye wot wel what I meene of this ꝑper/parde
as god me helpe / I laugh whan I thynke
how pitously a nyght / I made hem swynke
but bi my fay / I tolde of hit no store
thei hadde me yeve here londe / ⁊and here tresore
me nedede nought / do lenger diligence
to wynne here love / ⁊and do hem reủer/reence
they loued me so wel bi god above
that I ne tolde no deynte of here love
a wise woman wol besy hir eủer/ree in oon
to gete hir love / ye there as she hath noon
but sith I hadde hem / holly in myn honde
and that thei hadde / yeve me al here londe
what shulde I take kepe hem for to please
but if it were my ꝓprofyte / ⁊and myn ease
I sette hem so a worke / bi my fay
that many a night thei songen welaway
the Bacoıı̄un was not fette for hem I trowe
that som men han in Essex at Donmowe
I goủer/rened hem so wel after my lawe
that eche of hem / ful blisful was ⁊and fawe
to bringe me gay thingis / fro the feyre
knyvis ryngis ⁊and purses welfeyre
for god it wote I chidde hem spitously
now herkeneth how I bar me ꝓpropurly
¶ ye wise wivis / that can vnderstonde
thus shulde ye speke ⁊and bere hem wronge on honde
for halff so boldly / ther can no man
swere ⁊and lye / as a womman can
I sey not this / bi wommen that ben wise
but it be whan they hem mys avise
a wise wiff if that she can hir goode
shal bere hem on honde the kowe is woode
and take witnesse / of hir owne mayde
of hir assente / but herkeneth how I saide
sir olde keynarde / is this thin aray
whi is my neyghborus wiff so gay
she is honoured oủer/real where she goth
I sitte at hom I haue no thrifty cloth

On pite of this sike Damyan
That from hir herte / she ne drive can
The remembraunce / for to don him ease
C̉er/reteyne thoughte she / whom that this thing displese
I rekke nought / for here I him assure
To loue him best / of any creature
Though he no more had / than his sherte
Lo pite renneth sone / in gentil herte
Here may ye se / how excellent franchise
In women is / whan thei hem wel avise
Some tiraunt ther is / as ther ben many oon
That hath an herte as hard / as eny stoon ¶
Whiche wolde haue lete him sterve / in the place
Wel rather / than han graunted him that grace
And hem reioisen / in here cruel pride
And nought rekke to ben an homecide
¶ This gentil May / fulfilled of al pite
Right of hir owne honde / a letter made she
In whiche she graunted him / hir verry grace
Ther lakketh nought / but only day ⁊and place
Where that she myghte / to his luste suffice
For hit shal be / right as wo he wol devise
And whan she say hir tyme / vppon a day
To visite this Damyan / gooth feire May
And subtilly this lre / doun she thriste
Vnder his pelow / rede hit if him liste
She takith him bi the honde / ⁊and harde him twiste
So secretly / that no wight hit wiste
And bad him be al hool / ⁊and forth she wente
To Ianuarie / whan he for hir sente
¶ Vppe risith Damyan / the nexte morowe
Al passed was his sikenesse / ⁊and his sorowe
He kembith him proynith / ⁊and eke piketh
He doth it al that his lady list / ⁊and liketh
And eke to Ianuarie / he goth as lowe
As eủer/re did a dogge / for the bowe
He is so plesaunt / to eủer/rey man
For crafte is al / who so do hit can
That eủer/rey wight is feyne / to speke him good
And fully in his lady is grace he stood
Thus lete I Damyan / aboughte his nede
And in my tale forth / I wol procede
Some clerkis halden / that felicite
Stante in delite / ⁊and therfore c̉er/reteyne he
This noble Ianuarie / with al his myght
In honeste wise / that longeth to a knyght
Shope him to live / ful deliciously
His housyng / his aray / as honestly ¶
To his degre was maked / as a kynges
Among other / of his honeste thinges
He had a gardeyne / walled al with stoon
So feire agardeyne / woot I nowhere noon
For out of doute I verryly suppose
That he that wroote the romaunce of the rose
Ne couth of hit the beaute wel deuyse
Ne Priapus ne myght not suffice
Though he be god of gardeyns / for to telle
The beaute of the gardeyne ⁊and of the welle
That stood vnder a laurer / alwey grene
Ful ofte tyme kyng Pluto / ⁊and his quene
Preserpyna / ⁊and al hir feirie
Disporten hem / ⁊and maken melodie
Aboughte that welle / ⁊and daunced as men tolde
This noble knyght this Ianuarie the olde
Such deynte hath / in hit to walke ⁊and pleye
That he wol suffre no wight / bere the keye
Saue he him silff of the smale wiket
He bare alwey / of siluer a cleket
With the which whan that him list / vnshette
And whan that he wolde / pay his wiff hir dette
In some seson / theder wolde he go
And May his wiff / ⁊and no wight but thei two
And thinges that were not don abedde
He in the gardeyne ꝑper/parformed hem ⁊and spedde
And in this wise / many a mery day
Lived this Ianuarie / ⁊and fressh May
But worldly ioy / may not alwey dure
To Ianuarie / ne to no mane creature
O sodeyne happ o thow fortune vnstable
Like to the skorpioun / so disseivable
That flaterist with thin hede / whom thow wilt stynge
Thi taile is deth / thorugh thin envenemynge
O brotel ioy o swete poison / queynte
O monstre / that so subtily / canst peynte ¶
Thi yiftes vnder the hewe of stedfastnesse
Yit thow disseivist / both more ⁊and lesse
Whi hastow Ianuarie / thus disseivid
And haddist him / for thi ful frende resseived
And now thow hast birafte him / both his eighen
For sorow of whiche / desireth he to dien
Allas this noble Ianuarie that is so fre
Amydde his lust / ⁊and his prosꝑper/parite
Is woxen blynde / ⁊and that al sodeynly
His deth therfore / desirith he vtterly
And ther withal / the fire of ielousie
Leste that his wiff / shulde falle in some folie
So brente his herte / that he wolde fayn
That som man / both him ⁊and hir had slayn
For neủer/re after his deth / ne in his liff
Ne wolde he that she were loue ne wiff
But eủer/re live as a widowe / in clothis blake
Sool as a turtil doth that hath lost hir make
But at the laste / after a monthe or tweye
His sorow gan to swage / soth to seye
For whan he wiste / hit myght noon other be
He paciently / tooke his adủer/resite
Saue out of doute / may he not forgoon
That he nas ielous / eủer/re more in oon
Whiche ielousie / hit was so outragious
That neither in halle / ne in noon other hous
Ne in noon other place / neủer/re the mo
He nolde suffre hir / for to ride ne go
But yiff that he hadde / honde on hir alway
For which ofte wepith / feire fressh May
That lovith Damyan / so benyngnely
That she moot outher deien sodeynly
Or ellis she moot han him / at hir leste
She waitith whan hir herte / wolde breste
Vppon that other side / eke Damyan
Bicomen is the sorowfullest man ¶
That eủer/re was / for neither night ne day
Ne myghte he speke o worde / to fressh May
As to his purpos / of no such matere
But if that Ianuarie / moste hit here
That had an honde / vppon hir eủer/re mo
But natheles / bi writyng to ⁊and fro
And privi signys / wiste he what she mente
And she knewe eke the fyne / of his entente
O Ianuarie / what myght hit the avayle
Though thow myghtest se / as fer as shippis saile
For as good hit is / blynde disseived be
As to be disseived / whan a man may se
Lo Argus / that hadde an hundred eighen
For al that he couthe poure / or prien
Yit was he blynt / ⁊and god woot so ben mo
That wenyn wisly / that hit nys not so
Passe oủer/re is an ease / ⁊and sey no more
This fresshe May / of which I spake of yore
In warm wexe hath enpreynted the cleket
That Ianuarie bare / of the smale wiket
Bi whiche in to his gardeyne / ofte he wente
And Damyan / that knewe / al hir entente
The cleket conterfeted / ful pvily
Ther is no more to sey / but hastily
Some wonder / bi this cleket shal bityde
Whiche ye shulle hire / ⁊and ye wolle abide
¶ O noble Ovide / ful soth is seide god woote
What slight is hit / though it be longe ⁊and hoote
That he nyl fynde hit out / in some mane
Bi Piramus ⁊and Thesbe / may men lere
Though they were kept / ful streight oủer/real
Thei ben acorded / rownyng thorugh a wal
Ther is no wight couthe fynde / suche a sleighte
But now to purpos / er that dayes . viijte .
Were passed or the monthe of Iuyl bifille
That Ianuarie hath caughte / so grete a wille ¶
Thorugh eggyng of his wiff / him for to pleye
In his gardeyne / ⁊and no wight but they tweye
That in a morowe / vnto this May seide he
Rise vp my wiff my loue / my lady fre
The turtlis vois is I herde / my douve swete
The wynter is goon / with al his reignes wete
Com forthe with thin eighen columbyne
Ful feirer ben thi brestis / than is wyne
The gardeyne is enclosed / al aboute
Com forth my white spouse / oute of doute
Thow hast me wounded in myn herte o wiff
No spot in the nas / in al thi liff
Com forth ⁊and late vs take oure disporte
I chese yow for my wiff / ⁊and my comforte
Suche olde levde wordis / vsed he
On Damyan a signe made she
That he shulde go bifore / with his cliket
This Damyan / than opened the wiket
And in he sterte anoon / in suche mane
That no wight myght hit se ne here
And stille he sitte vnder abussh aloon
This Ianuarie as blynde is as a stoon
With May in his honde / ⁊and no wight moo
In to his fresshe gardeyn / ben thei goo
And clapt to the wiket / sodeynly
Now wiff qd he / here nys but ye ⁊and I
That arte the creature / that I best loue
For bi that lord / that sitte vs alle aboue
I had leuer to deien / on a knyff
Than yow offende / my trewe dere wiff
For godis sake thenke / how I yow chees
Nought for no couetise doutelees
But only for the loue I had to the
And though that I be olde / ⁊and may not se
Be to me trewe / ⁊and I wol telle yow whi
Thre thinges certis shal ye wynne therby ¶
First loue of criste / ⁊and to youre silff honoure
And al myn heritage / both town ⁊and toure
I yeve hit yow / makith charters as yow liste
This shal be don to morowe / er sonne vp riste
So wisly god my soule brynge at blisse
I pray yow first in couenaunt ye me kisse
And though that I be ielous / wite me nought
Ye ben so depe enprented / in my thought
That whan I considre / yowre beaute
And therwithal / the vnlikly elde of me
I may not c̉er/retis / though I sholde dye
For bere to ben out of youre companye
For verry loue this is / withouten doute
Now kisse me wiff / ⁊and lete vs roome aboute
This fresshe May / whan she these wordis herde
Benyngnely to Ianuarie she answerde
But first ⁊and forward / she bigan to wepe
I haue qd she a soule for to kepe
As wel as ye / ⁊and also myn honour
And of my wiffhede / thilke tendre flour
Whiche that I haue assured / in youre honde
Whan the preste to yow / my body bonde
Wherfore I wol answere / in this mane
With the leue of yow / my lord so dere
I pray to god / that neủer/re dawe that day
That I ne sterve as foule / as woman may
If eủer/re I do vn to my kyn that shame
Or ellis I enpeire so / my name
That I be fals ⁊and if I do that lakke
To stripe me / ⁊and putte me in a sakke
And in the next revere / do me drenche
I am agentil woman / ⁊and no wenche
Whi speke ye thus / but men ben eủer/re vntrewe
And women han repreff of yow / ay newe
Ye can noon other contenaunce / I leve
But speke to vs of vnthriste ⁊and repve ¶
And with that worde she saw where Damyan
Sat in the busshe / ⁊and knele he bigan
And with hir fynger / signes made she
That Damyan shulde clymbe / vppon a tre
That charged was with fruyte / ⁊and vp he wente
For verryly he knewe / al hir entente
And eủer/rey signe / that she couthe make
Wel bet than Ianuarie / hir owne make
For in a lett̉er/re she had tolde him al
Of this matere / how he werchen shal
And thus I lete him sitte / in the pery
And Ianuarie ⁊and May / rownyng ful mery
¶ Bright was the day / ⁊and blew the firmament
Phebus hath of gold / his stremes sente
To gladen eủer/rey floure / with his warmnesse
He was that tyme / in Gemynes / as I gesse
But litil fro his tyme / of declynacion
Of Cancer / ⁊and of Iouis exaltacion
And so bifil / in that bright morwe tide
That in the gardeyne / on the ferther side
Was Pluto that is kyng / of al feirie
And many a lady / in his companye
Folwyng his wiff / the quene Proserpyna
Whiche that he ravisshed out of ꝓproserpina
While that she gadered flouris / in a mede
In Claudyan / ye may the stories rede
How in his grisly carte he hir sette
This kyng of feirie / than adoun him sette
Vppon a benche of torvis / fresshe ⁊and grene
And right anoon thus seide he to his quene
My wiff qd he / ther may no wight sey nay
The exꝑper/parience pvith hit / eủer/rey day
The treson whiche that women / don to man
Ten hundred thousande / telle I can
Notable of youre vntrowthe / ⁊and brotilnes
Of Salamon richest / of al riches ¶
Fulfilled of sapience / ⁊and of worldly glorie
Ful worthi ben thi wordis / to memorie
To eủer/rey wight that witt ⁊and reson can
Thus preisith he yit / the bounte of man
Amonges athousande men / yit fonde I oon
But of women alle / fonde I neủer/re noon
Thus seith the kyng that knowith your wikkednes
And Ihc filius Sirak as I ges
Ne spekith of yow / but silde reủer/reence
A wilde fire / ⁊and a corupt pestilence
So falle vppon youre bodies / yit to nyght
Ne se ye nat / this honourable knyght
Bicause allas that he is blynde ⁊and oolde
His owne man / shal make him Cokewolde
Lo where he sitte / the lechoure in the tre
Now wol I graunte / of my mageste
Vnto this olde worthi / blynde knyght
That he shal han ayen / his eighen sight
Whan that his wiff / wolde do him vilonye
Than shal he knowe al hir harlotrie
Both in repreff of hir / ⁊and other moo
Ye shalt qd Proserpina / ⁊and wol ye soo
Now bi my moders siris soule / I swere
That I shal yeven hir / sufficiaunt answere
And alle women after / for hir sake
That though thei ben / in any gilt I take
With face bolde thei shulle hem silff excuse
And bere hem doun / that wolde hem accuse
For lak of answere / noon of hem shal deyen
Al had ye seyne athing / with both youre eyghen
Yit shul we women / so visage it hardely
And wepe ⁊and swere / ⁊and chide subtilly
So that ye men / shul be / as levde as gees
What recketh me / of youre auctoritees
¶ I woot wel this Iewe / this Salamon
Fonde of vs women foolis many oon ¶
But though that he / ne fonde no good woman
Ther hath I fonde / many another man
Women ful trewe / goode ⁊and v̉er/retuous
Witnes of hem / that dwellen in cristis hous
With martirdom / thei preved here constaunce
The Romayne gestis / maken remembraunce
Of many a verry / trewe wiff also
But sir ne be not wroth / al be hit so
Though that he seide / he fonde no good woman
I pray yow takith the sentence of the man
He mente thus / that in soủer/reeyne bounte
Nys noon but god / neither he ne she
Ey verry god / that nys but oon
What make ye so meche of Salamon
What though he made a temple godis hous
What though he were riche / ⁊and glorious
So made he a temple / of fals godis
Who myght do a thing / that more forboode is
ꝐPer/Parde als faire as ye / his name implastre
He was a lechour / ⁊and an ydolastre
And in his elde / he verry god forsooke
And if god ne hadde / as seith the booke
I sparid him for his fadris sake / he sholde
Haue loste his reigne / rather than he wolde
I sette nought of al the vilonye
That ye of women write a boterflye
I am a woman / nedis mot I speke
Or ellis swelle til myn herte breke
For sithen he seide / that we ben iangeleresses
As eủer/re mot I brouke bothe my tresses
I shal not spare / for no curtesie
To speke him harm / that wolde vs vilonye
Dame qd this Pluto / be no lenger wroothe
I yeve hit vp / but sith I swore myn oothe
That I wolde graunte him / his sight agayn
My worde shal stonde / that warne I the c̉er/retayn ¶
I am a kyng / hit sitte me not to lye
And I a quene qd she of the feyrie
Hir answere shal she haue / I vnder take
Lete vs no mo wordis / here of make
For soth / I wol no lenger yow contrarie
Now lete vs turne ageyne to Ianuarie
That in the gardeyne / with his fressh May
Syngeth ful meryere / than the popyngay
¶ Yow loue I beste / ⁊and shal ⁊and other noon
So longe aboute the aley is / is he goon
Til he was comyn / ageyns the Perye
Where as this Damyan / sitteth ful merye
An high a monge the fressh levis grene
This fressh May / that is so bright ⁊and shene
Gan for to sike / ⁊and seide allas my side
Now sir qd she for aught that may bitide
I moste haue / of the perys / that I se
Or I mot dye / so sore longeth me
To eten of the smale peris grene
Helpe for hir loue / that is of heuen quene
I telle yow wel / a woman in my plighte
May haue to fruyte / so grete an appetite
That she may dye / but she hit haue
Allas qd he / that I nad here a knaue
That coude clymbe / allas allas qd he
That I am blynde / ye sir no fors qd she
But wolde ye vouchesaff / for godis sake
The pery withinne youre armes to take
For wel I woot / that ye mystrute me
Than shulde I clymbe / wel I now qd she
So I my fote myght sette / vppon youre bak
For soth qd he / in me shal be no lak
Myght I yow helpen / with myn herte bloode
He stoupith down / ⁊and on his bak she stoode
And caughte hir bi a twiste / ⁊and vp she goothe
Ladyes I pray yow / be ye not wroothe ¶
I can not glose / I am a rude man
And sodeynly / anoon this Damyan
Gan pulle vp the smok / ⁊and in he thronge
And whan that Pluto saw / that grete wronge
To Ianuarie he gaff ageyne / his sight
And made him se / as wel as eủer/re he myght
And whan that he / had his sight agayne
Ther was neủer/re man of thing / so fayne
But on his wiff / his thought was eủer/re mo
Vp to the tre / he caste his eyghen two
And saw how Damyan / his wiff had dressed
In suche mane / hit may not ben expressed
But if I wolde speke / vncurteysly
And vp he gaff / a roryng ⁊and a cry
As doth the moder / whan the childe shal dye
Oowte helpe allas / harrow he gan crye
O stronge lady stoure / what doist thow
And she answerde / sir what eylith yow
Haue pacience ⁊and resoıı̄un / in youre mynde
I have yow holpen / on both youre eyghen blynde
Vp perel of my soule / I shal not lyen
As me was tavght / to hele with youre eyghen
Was nothing bet / to make yow se
Than strogle with a man / vppon a tre
God woot I did hit / in ful good entente
Stride qd he / ye algate in hit wente
God yeve yow both / on shames deth to dien
He did the so / I sigh it with myn eyghen
And ellis be I honged / by the hals
Than is qd she / my medicyne al fals
For c̉er/reteynly / if that ye myghten see
Ye wolde not seye / tho wordis vnto me
Ye han som glymsyng / ⁊and no ꝑper/parfite sight
I se qd he as wel / as eủer/re I myght
Thonked be god / with both myn eyghen two
And bi my trouthe me thoughte / he did the so ¶
Ye mase mase goode sir / qd she
This thanke haue I / for I haue made yow se
Allas qd she / that eủer/re I was so kynde
Now dame qd he / lete al passe out of mynde
Com down my lef / ⁊and if I haue myssaide
God helpe me so / as I am euel apaide
But bi my fader soule / I wende haue seyne
How that this Damyan / had bi the leyne
And that thi smok / had leyne vppon thi brest
Ye sir qd she / ye may wene as yow lest
But sir a man that wakith out of his slepe
He may not sodeynly / ne wel taken kepe
Vppon a thing / ne sen hit ꝑper/parfitly
Til that he ben a dawed / verrily
Right so a man / that longe hath blynde I be
Ne may not sodeynly / so wel I se
First whan his sight / is newe com ageyne
As he that hath / a day or two I seyne
Til that youre sight / I stabled be a while
Ther may ful many a sight / yow bigile
Beth war I pray yow / for bi heuen kyng
Ful many a man wenyth / to se a thing
And hit is al another / than hit semeth
He that mysconceivith / mys demeth
And with that worde / she lepe doun fro the tre
This Ianuarie / who is glad but he
He kissith hir / ⁊and clippith hir / ful ofte
And on hir wombe / he stroketh hir ful softe
And to his paleys hoom / he hath hir lad
Now goode men I pray yow / to be glad
Thus endith here my tale / of Ianuarie
God blesse vs / ⁊and his moder seynt Marie . Amen .

Here endith the Marchauntis tale of Ianuarie
And May . and bigynneth the Squyers ꝓprolog

Here endith the Marchauntis tale of Ianuarie
And May . and bigynneth the Squyers ꝓprolog
Ey godis mcy / seide oure ost tho
Now such a wiff / I pᵃy god kepe vs fro ¶
Lo whiche slighthis / ⁊and sotilteis
In women ben / for thei be besy as beis
To vs sely men / for to disseive
And fro a soth / eủer/re wol thei weive
Bi this marchauntis tale / hit pvith wele
But douteles as trewe as any stele
I haue a wiff / though she pore be
But of hir tonge / a labbyng shrewe is she
And yit she hath an hepe / of vicis mo
Therof no force / lete al such thingis go
But woot ye what / in consail be hit seide
Me rewith sore / I am to hir I teyde
For ⁊and I sholde reken / eủer/rey mane vise
Whiche that she hath / I wis I were to nyse
And cause whi / hit sholde reported be
And tolde to hir / bi some of this mayne
Bi whom it nedith not / to declare
Syn women / conne outere suche cheffare
And eke my witt / suffisith not ther to
To tellen al / therfore my tale is do
Squyer com nere / if that youre wille be
And sey somwhat of loue / for c̉er/retis ye
Konne theron / asmech as any man
Nay sir qd he / but I wol sey as I can
With herty wil / for I wol not rebelle
Ageyne youre lust / a tale wol I telle
Haue me excused / if that I speke a mys
My wil is good / ⁊and lo my tale is this .

Here endith the Squyers prolog And
next folwying bigynneth his tale .

And hurlist al fro the est / to the occidente
And naturelly wolde holde / another way
Thi croudyng sitteth the heuen / in such array
At the bigynnyng / of this fers viage
That cruel Mars hath slayne / this mariage
¶ Infortunate ascendent / tortuous ¶
Of whiche the lorde is helpeles falle allas
Out of his angle / into the derkest hous
O Mars as in this caas
O feble mone / vnhappy be thi paas
Thow knettest the / there thow art nought resceived
There thow were wel / fro thens artow now weived
¶ Imprudent Emꝑper/parour̉er/re of Rome allas
Was ther no Philosophre / in al thi toun
Is no tyme bet than other / in such cas
Of viage is ther noon eleccioun
Namely to folke / of highe condicion
Nat whan a rote / is of a birthe I knowe
Allas ye ben to levde / or to slowe
¶ To shippe is brought / this woful faire maide
Solempnely / with eủer/rey circumstaunce
Now ihu criste / be with yow alle she saide
There is no more / but farewel faire Custaunce
She peyneth hir to make / good contenaunce
And forth I lete hir sayle / in this mane
And turne I wol ageyne / to my matere
¶ The moder of the Souldan / welle of vicis
Espiede hath hir sones pleyne entente
How he wol lete / his olde sacrificis
And right anoon she for hir consaile sente
And thei come to knowen / what she mente
And whan assembled was / this folke infere
She sette hir doun / ⁊and seide as ye shul here
¶ Lordes she seide / ye knowe eủer/reychon
How that my sone inpoynte is for to lete
The holy lawes of oure Alkaron
Yeven bi godis messager Makomete
But oon avowe / to grete god I hete
The liff shal rather / out of my body sterte
Or Makametis lawe / go out of myn herte
¶ What sholde vs tiden / of this newe lawe
But thraldom / to oure bodies ⁊and penaunce ¶
And afterward in helle / to be drawe
For we renyede Mahon / oure creaunce
But lordes wil ye maken assuraunce
As I shal seyne / assentyng to my lore
And I shal make vs sauff / for eủer/remore
¶ Thei sworen ⁊and assenten / eủer/rey man
To live with hir / ⁊and deye / ⁊and bi hir stonde
And eủer/reych in the best wise he can
To strengthen hir / shal alle his frendis Fonde
And she hath this emprise / take on honde
Whiche ye shal hire / that I shal devise
And to hem alle she spak / in this wise
¶ We shulle first feyne vs / cristendom to take
Colde water shal not greve vs / but alite
And I shal such afeste / ⁊and reuel make
That as I trowe / I shal the Souldan quyte
For though his wiff be cristened neủer/re so white
She shal haue nede / to wasshe a wey the rede
Though she a fonte ful of wat̉er/re / with hir lede
¶ O soudonesse / rote of iniquite
Virago thow Semyrian the secounde
O serpent / vnder femenite
Like to the serpent / depe in helle I bounde
O feyned woman / al that may confounde
Vertu ⁊and innocence thorugh thi malice
Is bred in the as nest of eủer/rey vice
¶ O sathan envious / syn thilke day
That thow were chased / from oure heritage
Wel knowest thow to women / the olde way
Thow madist Eue bringe vs in suage
Thow wolt fordon / this cristen mariage
Thin instrument / so wel away the while
Makist thow woman whan thow wolt bigile
¶ This Souldanesse whom I thus blame ⁊and warye
Lete pⁱrivily hir consail gon there waye
What sholde I in this tale lenger tarye ¶
She rideth to the Souldan on a day
And seide / she wolde renye hir lay
And cristendom of prestis hondes fonge
Repentyng hir / she hethen was so longe
¶ Biseching him / to don hir that honoure
That she myghte haue the cristen folke to feste
To plese hem / I wol do my laboure
The Souldan seith / I wol do at youre heste
And knelyng thonkith hir / of that requeste
So glad he was / he nyst what to seye
She kissed hir sone / ⁊and hom she goth hir weye
¶ Arrived ben these cristen folke / to londe
In Surrye with agrete solempne route
And hastily this Souldan sente his sonde
First to his moder / ⁊and to al the regne aboute
And seide his wiff was comen / oute of doute
And praide hir for to rn / ayenst the quene
The honour of his regne to sustene
¶ Grete was the pres / ⁊and riche was the araye
Of Surreyens ⁊and Romayns / mette infere
The moder of the Souldan / riche ⁊and gaye
Resceivith hir / with also glad a chere
As any moder myghte hir doughter dere
And to the nexte cite / there biside
A soft pas / solempnely / thei ride
¶ Nought trow I / the tryumphe of Iulius
Of whiche that Lucan / makith such a booste
Was royaller / ne more curious
Than was thassemble / of this blisful hooste
But this skorpion / this wikked gooste
This Souldanesse / for al hir flaterynge
Cast vnder this / ful mortally to stynge
¶ The Souldan cometh him silff / soone aft̉er/re this
So royally / that wonder was to telle
And welcometh hir / with alle ioye ⁊and blis
And thus in merthe ⁊and ioye I lete hem duelle ¶
The fruyte of eủer/rey tale / is for to telle
Whan tyme cam men thought it for the beste
That reuel stynte / ⁊and men gon to reste
¶ The tyme cam / this olde Souldanesse
Ordeyned hath this feste of whiche I tolde
And to the feste / cristen folke hem dresse
In genal / both yonge ⁊and olde
There may men feste / ⁊and roialte biholde
And deyntees mo / than I can devise
But al to dere thei boughte hit / or thei rise
¶ O sodeyne wo / that eủer/re art successour
To worldly blis / spreynte is with bitt̉er/renes
The ende of oure ioye / ⁊and oure wordly labour
Wo ocupieth the fyne / of oure gladnes
Herken this I consaile for thi securenes
Vppon thi glad day / haue in mynde
The vnwar wo or harme / that cometh behynde
¶ For shortly to tellen / at o worde
The Souldan / ⁊and the cristen eủer/reychone
Ben al to hewe / ⁊and stiked / at the borde
But it were only dame Custaunce alone
This olde Souldanesse / this cursed crone
Hath with hir frendes / don this cursed dede
For she hir silff / wolde al the contre lede
¶ Ne there nas Surreyne noon / that was conủer/reted
That of the consaile / of the Souldan woote
That he nas al to hewen / or he asterted
And Custaunce haıı thei take / anoon fote hoote
And in a shipp stereles / god hit woote
Thei haue hir sette / ⁊and bad hir lerne to saile
Oute of Surrey / ayenward to ytaile
¶ A c̉er/reteyne tresoure / that she theder ladde
And soth to seyne / vitaille grete plente
Thei haue hir yeven / ⁊and clothis eke she hadde
And forth she sailith / in the salte se
O my Custaunce ful of benignite ¶
O Emꝑper/parouris yonge doughter dere
He that is lorde / oủer/re fortune be thi stere
¶ She blissith hir ⁊and with aful piteous voice
Vn to the croys of crist / thus seide she
O clere o welful auter / holy croice
Rede of the lambes blode / ful of pite
That whisse the world / fro the olde iniquite
Me fro the fende / ⁊and from his clawis kepe
That day that I shal drenchen in the depe
¶ Victorious tre / proteccion of trewe
That onely worthi were / for to bere
The kynge of heuen / with his woundes newe
The white lambe / that hurte was with a peresperespere
Flemer of fendes / oute of heuen ⁊and here
On whiche thi lynes / feithfully extenden
Me kepe ⁊and yeve myghte / my liff to amenden
¶ Yeres ⁊and dayes / fleteth this creature
Thorughoute the se of Grece / in to the straite
Of Marrok / as it was hir auenture
On many a sory mele may she baite
After hir deth / ful ofte may she waite
Er that the wilde wawes / wolde hir drive
Vn to the place / there she shal arive
¶ Men myghte axen / why she was not sleyne
Eke at the feste / who myghte hir body saue
I answere to that demaunde ayeyne
Who saued Danyel in the orrible caue
There eủer/rey wight saf he / maist̉er/re or knaue
Was with the lioıı̄uns frete / or thei asterte
No wight but god / that he bare in his herte
¶ God leste to shewe / his wonderful miracle
In hir / for she sholde se his myghti werkis
Criste that is / to eủer/rey harme triacle
Bi c̉er/reteyne meenes ofte as knowen clerkis
Doth thing for c̉er/reteyne ende / that ful derke is
To mannes witte / that for oure ignoraunce ʳ¶

¶ Now sen she was not / at the feste slawe
Who kept hir fro drenching / in the see
Who kept Ionas / in the fisshis mawe
Til he were spouted vp / at Nineve
Wel may men knowe / hit was no wight but he
That kept the peple Ebraik / from drenchinge
With drie fete / thorughout the see passinge
¶ Who hadde the iiij spirites of tempeste
That power̉er/re haıı to noyen londe / ⁊and see
Both north ⁊and south ⁊and also west ⁊and Este
Anoyeth nether see / ne londe / ne tre
Sothly the commaunder of that was he
That fro the tempest / ay hshishis woman kepte
As wel whan she woke / as whan she slepte
¶ Where myghte this woman mete ⁊and drynke haue
Thre yere ⁊and more / how lasteth hir vitaile
Who fedde the Egipcian Marie / in the caue
Or in deserte / noon but crist saunce faile
Five thousand folke / it was a grete mervaile
With loues five / ⁊and fisshis two to fede
God sente his foison / at hir grete nede
SHe drivith for the / in oure Occian
Thorughoute the wilde se / til at the laste
Vnder a castel / that nempne I ne can
Fer in Northhumbrelond / the wawes hir caste
And in the sonde / hir shipp steked so faste
That thens nolde it nought / al a tyde
The wil of criste was / that she shulde abide
¶ The constable of this castel / doun is fare
To sen this wrakke / ⁊and al the shipp he soughte
And this wery woman / ful of care
He fonde also the tresoure that she broughte
And in hir langage / mcy she bisoughte
The liff oute of the body for to twynne
Hir to delyuer of woo that she was Inne ¶
¶ A maner latine corrupte was hir speche
But algates therby was she vnderstonde
The constable whan him leste no lenger seche
This wooful woman / brought he to the londe
She kneled doun / ⁊and thonked cristis sonde
But what she was she wolde to noman seye
For foule ne feire / though she sholde deye
¶ She seide she was / so mased in the see
That she forgate hir mynde / bi hir trouthe
The constable of hir hath so grete pite
And eke his wiff / that thei wepen for routhe
She was so diligente withouten slouthe
To sue ⁊and plese eủer/reych in that place
That alle hir louen / that loken in hir face
¶ The Constable ⁊and dame Hermygeld his wiff
Were payneins / ⁊and that contre eủer/rey where
But Hermegeld loued hir as hir liff
And Custaunce hath so longe soiorned there
In orisoıı̄uns with many a bitter tere
Til Ihus haue conủer/reted / thorugh his grace
Dame Hermegeld wiff to the Constable of that place
¶ In al that londe no cristen dorst route
Al cristen men / ben fled fro that contre
Thorugh paynenis that conquerid al aboute
The plages of the northe / bi the londe ⁊and the see
To wales fledde the cristianite
Of olde bretons duelling in this Ile
There was here refute for the meene while
¶ But yit nere cristen bretons so exiled
That there nas some in here privite
Honoured crist ⁊and hethen folke begiled
And nyghe the Castel suche there duelte thre
That oon of hem was blynde ⁊and myghte not se
But it were with thilke eyghen of his mynde
With whiche men sen / after thei ben blynde
¶ Bright was the sonne as in the somes day ¶
For which the Constable ⁊and his wiff also
And Custaunce / haue I take the right way
Toward the se / aforlonge wey or two
To pleyen ⁊and romen to ⁊and fro
And in this walke / the blynde men thei mette
Croked ⁊and olde with eyghen faste I shette
¶ In the name of criste / cried this blynde bretoıı̄un
Dame Hermegeld yeue me my sighte ageyne
This lady wex affraide / of the soun
Leste hir housbonde / shortly for to seyne
Wolde hir for ihu cristis loue / haue sleyne
Til Custaunce made hir bolde / ⁊and bad hir wirche
The wil of criste / as dought̉er/re of his chirche
¶ The Constable wex abasshed of that sighte
And seide what amountith / al this fare
Custaunce answerde / hit is cristis myghte
That helpith folke / oute of the fendis snare
And so forforthe / she gan oure feith declare
That she the Constable / or hit were eeve
Conủer/reted hath / ⁊and on criste made him bileve
¶ This Constable was not lord / of that place
Of which I speke / there he Custaunce fonde
But kept hit strongly / many a wynt̉er/re space
Vnder Alla / kyng of Northhumbrelonde
That was ful wise ⁊and worthi / of his honde
Ageine the scottis / as men may wel here
But turne I wil ageyne to my matere
Sathan that euer vs waiteth to begile
Saw of Custaunce / al hir ꝑper/parfeccioıı̄un
And caste anoon / how he myghte quite hir while
And made a yonge knyght / that duelte in that toun
Loue hir so hoote / of foule affeccioun
That verryly him thoughte he sholde spille
But he of hir / onys myghte haue his wille
¶ He wowith hir / but hit availith nought
She wolde do no synne bi noweye ¶
And for dispite / he compassed in his thought
To make hir on shameful deth to deye
He waiteth whan the Constable was a weye
And privily on a nighte he crepte
In to Hermegeldis chambre whiles she slepte
¶ Wery for waked ihinhn there orisoıı̄uns
Slepte Custaunce / ⁊and hermegeld also
This knyght thorugh sathanas is temptacioıı̄uns
Al softely he is to the bed I go
And kitte Hermegeldis throte atwo
And leide the blody knyff / bi dame Custaunce
And wente his weye / there god yeve him mischaunce
¶ Sone after cometh the Constable hom ageyne
And eke Alla / that was kyng / of the londe
And saw his wiff / dispitously sleyne
For which ful ofte he wepte / ⁊and wronge his honde
And in the bed / the blody knyff he fonde
Bi dame Custaunce / allas what myghte she seye
For verry wo / hir witt was al aweye
¶ To kyng Alla was tolde al this mischaunce
And eke the tyme / ⁊and where ⁊and in what wise
That in a shipp was founden this Custaunce
As ye here aforne / haue herde devise
The kynges herte of pite gan agrise
Whan he saw so benigne a creature
Falle in desese / ⁊and in mysauenture
¶ For as the lambe toward his deth is brought
So stant this innocent / bifore the kyng
This fals knyght that hath this treson wrought
Berith hir on honde that she hath do this thing
But natheles there was grete mornyng
Amonge the peple / ⁊and seiden thei can not gesse
That she had don / so grete a wikkednesse
¶ For thei haue seyne hir / eủer/ree so vertuouse
And lovyng Hermegeld right as hir liff
Of this bare wittenesse eủer/reych in that house ¶
Saue he that slough Hermegeld with his knyff
This gentil kyng hath caught a grete motiff
Of this wittenes ⁊and thoughte he wolde enquere
Depper in this caas / the trouthe for to lere
¶ Allas Custaunce thow naste no champion
Ne fighte canst thow not so welaway
But he that for oure redempcion
Bounde sathan ⁊and lyth yit there he lay
He be thi stronge champion / this day
For but if criste / open miracle kithe
Withouten gilt thow shalt be sleyne ful swithe
¶ She sett hir doun on knees / ⁊and thus she seidesaideseaide
Immortal god that sauedist Susane
From fals blame / ⁊and thow mciful maide
Marie I meene doughter of seint Anne
Biforne whos childe angels singe Osanne
If I be giltles of this felonye
My socour be or ellis shal I dye
¶ Haue ye not seyne sum tyme a pale face
Amonge apres / of him that hath be ladde
Toward his deth where him get no grace
And suche a colour in his face hath hadde
That men myghte knowe his face that was bistadde
Amonge alle the faces in that route
So stante Custaunce / ⁊and loketh hir aboute
¶ O quenys lynage in prosꝑper/parite
Duchesses ⁊and ladies eủer/reychone
Haue som routhe on hir adủer/resite
An Emꝑper/parours doughter stant alone
She hath no wight to whom to make hir moone
O blode roial that stondist in this drede
Fer ben thi frendis at thi grete nede
¶ This Alla kyng hath suche compassioun
As gentil herte is fulfilled of pite
That from his eyhen ran the water doun
Now hastily do feche a booke qd he ¶
And if this knyght wol swere how that she
This woman slough yit wil we vs avise
Whom that we wolde that shal be oure Iustice
¶ A breton booke wreten / with the Euuangelises
Was fette / ⁊and on this booke he swore anone
She gilty was / ⁊and in the mene whiles
An honde him smote / vppon the necke bone
That doun he fil atones / as a stone
And both his eyghen borste oute of his face
In sight of eủer/rey body / in that place
¶ A voice was herde / in genal audience
And seide thow hast disclaundred gilteles
The doughter of holy chirche / in high psence
Thus hast thow don / ⁊and yit I holde my pees
Of this mvaile / agast was al the pres
As mased folke / thei stoden eủer/reychone
For drede of wreche / saue Custaunce alone
¶ Grete was the drede ⁊and eke the repentaunce
Of hem that hadden / wronge suspecion
Vppon this sely innocente Custaunce
And for this miracle / in conclusion
And bi Custaunces / mediacion
The kyng ⁊and many another in that place
Conủer/reted was / thonked be cristes grace
¶ This fals knyght / was sleyne for his vntrouthe
By iugement of Alla / hastily
And yit had Custaunce / of his deth grete routhe
And after this / Ihus of his mcy
Made Alla wedden / ful solempnely
This holy maiden / that is so bright ⁊and shene
And thus hath criste made Custaunce a quene
¶ But who was woful if I shal not lye
Of this wedding / but Donegild ⁊and nomo
The kyngis moder / ful of tirannye
Hir thoughte hir cursed herte braste atwo
She wolde not hir sone / had doıı̄un so ¶
Hir thought adispite that he sholde take
So strange acreature / vnto his make
¶ Me lest not of the chaff / ne of the stre
Make so longe a tale / as of the corne
What sholde I tellen / of the roialte
Of the mariage / or which cours goth to forne
Who blowith in a trompe / or in an horne
The fruyte of eủer/rey tale / is for to seie
Thei ete ⁊and drinke / ⁊and daunce / ⁊and singe / ⁊and pleie
¶ Thei gon to bedde / as hit was skil ⁊and right
For though that wivis ben / ful holy thinges
Thei most take in pacience / at night
Suche maner necessaries / as ben plesinges
To folke that haue wedded hem / with rynges
And leye alitil / there holynes a side
As for the tyme / it may non other betide
¶ On hir he gate / aman childe anoon
And to a buschip / ⁊and his Constable eke
He toke his wiff to kepe / whan he is goon
To scottelonde ward / his foomen for to seke
Now faire Custaunce / that is so humble ⁊and meke
So longe is gon with childe / til that stille
She holt hir chambre / abidyng cristis wille
¶ The tyme is come / aman childe she on bere
Mauricius at the fonte / thei him calle
This Constable doth forth come a messagere
And wrote to his kyng / that cleped was Alle
How that this blisful tidinges / was bifalle
And other thinges spedful / for to seye
He taketh the letter / ⁊and forth he goth his weye
¶ This messager / to don his auantage
Vn to the kynges moder / rideth swithe
And salueth hir ful faire / in his langage
Madame qd he / ye may be glad ⁊and blithe
And thonken god / an hundred thousand sithe
My lady the quene hath childe withoute doute ¶
To ioy ⁊and blisse / of al this regne aboute
¶ Lo here the lettres selid / of this tithinge
That I mote bere / with al the haste I may
If ye wil ought / vn to youre sone the kynge
I am youre seruaunt / both night ⁊and day
Dame Donegild answerde / at this tyme nay
But here al night I wil / that thow take thi reste
To morow wil I sey the / what me leste
¶ This messager dranke sadly / ale ⁊and wyne
And stolen were his lettres privily
Out of his box / while he slepte as a swyne
And conterfetid was / ful subtily
And other lres wreten / ful synfully
Vnto the kyng directe / of this matere
Fro his Constable / as ye shal after here
¶ The letter spak / how the quene delyủer/reed was
Of so horrible a fendely creature
That in the Castel / noon so hardy nas
That any while dorste / therinne endure
The moder was an Elff / bi auenture
I come by charmes / or bi sorcerie
And eủer/rey wight hateth / hir o companye
¶ Woo was the kyng / whan he this letter had seyne
But to no wight / he tolde his sowesorwesorwe sore
But of his owne honde he wroote / ageyne
Welcome be the sonde of crist / for eủer/re more
To me that am now / lerned in his lore
Lord welcome be thi lust / ⁊and thi plesaunce
My lust I put al in thin ordynaunce
¶ Kepith this childe / al be hit foule or feire
And eke my wiff / vnto myn hom comynge
Criste whan him list / may sende me an heire
More agreable than this / to my likynge
This lre he seleth / privily wepynge
Which to the messager was taken sone
And forth he goth ther is no more to done ¶
¶ O messager fulfils of dronkennesse
Stronge is thi brethe / thi lemes faltern ay
And thow bewriest / al sekernesse
Thi mynde is lorne / thow Iangelest as a Iay
Thi face is torned / into a newe aray
There dronkenesse regneth / in any route
There is no consaile hid / withouten doute
¶ O Donegild I haue noon englisshe digne
Vn to thi malice / ⁊and thi tirannye
And therfore to the fende / I the resigne
Lat him enditen / thi trayterye
Fy mannysshe fy o nay bigod I lye
Fy fendely spirit / for I dar wel telle
Though thow here walke / thi spirit is in helle
¶ This messager cometh fro the kyng agayne
And at the kyngis moders courte he lighte
And she was of this messager / ful fayne
And plesed him in al that eủer/re she myghte
He dranke ⁊and wel his girdil vnder pighte
He slepith ⁊and he snowrith in his gise
Al night til the sone gan rise
¶ Efte were his lettres stolen eủer/reychon
And conterfetid lres / in this wise
The kyng commaundith his Constable anoon
Vp peyne of hangyng / or on high Iewise
That he ne sholde suffre hir / in nowise
Constaunce / withinne his regne to abide
Thre dayes / ⁊and a quarter of a tide
¶ But in the same shipp / as he hir fonde
Hir ⁊and hir yonge sone / ⁊and al hir gere
He sholde putte / ⁊and croude fro the londe
And charge hir / that she neủer/re efte come there
O my Custaunce / wel may thi goste haue fere
And slepyng in thi drem / ben in penaunce
Whan Donegild / caste al this ordynaunce
¶ This messager on morowe / whan he wooke ¶
Vn to the Castel / halt the nexte way
And to the Constable / he the lett̉er/re tooke
And whan that he / this pitous lre say
Ful ofte he seide allas / ⁊and welaway
Lord criste qd he / how may this lre endure
So ful of synne / is many a creature
¶ O myghti god / if that it be thi wille
Sith thow art rightful Iuge / how may it be
That thow wolt suffren / innocentis to spille
And wikked folke / regnen in prosꝑper/parite
O good Custaunce / allas so wo is me
That moot be / thi tormentour or deye
On shames deth / ther is noon other weye
¶ Wepen both yonge ⁊and olde / in al that place
Whan that the kyng / this cursed lre sente
And Custaunce / with a dedly pale face
The ferthe day / toward hir shipp she wente
But natheles / she takith in good entente
The wil of crist / ⁊and knelyng in the stronde
She seide lord / ay welcome be thi sonde
¶ He that me kepte / fro the fals blame
While I was on the londe / amonges yow
He can me kepe / from harm ⁊and eke fro shame
In salt see / al though I se not how
As stronge as eủer/re he was / he is right now
In him truste I / ⁊and in his moder dere
That is to me / my saile ⁊and eke my stere
¶ Hir litil child / lay weping in hir arme
And kneling pitously to him she seide
Pees litel sone / I wol do the noon harme
With that the couerchief / of hir hede she breide
And oủer/re his litil eyghen / she it leyde
And in hir arme / she lullith it ful faste
And in to heuen / hir eyghen vp she caste
¶ Moder qd she / ⁊and maiden seint Marie
Soth is that thorugh womannes eggement ¶
Mankynde was lorn / ⁊and dampned ay to dye
For which thi childe / was on a croys I rent
Thi blisful eyghen / saw al his turment
Than is there / no comꝑper/parison bitwene
Thi wo / ⁊and any wo / man may sustene
¶ Thow saw thi sone slayne / bifore thin eighen
And yit now livith / my litil child ꝑper/parfaye
Now lady bright / to whom alle woful crien
Thow glorie of womanhode / thow faire maye
Thow haven of refute / bright sterre of the daye
Rewe on my childe / that of thi gentillesse
Rewest on eủer/rey reweful / in destresse
¶ O litil child allas / what is thi gilt
That neủer/re wroughtest synne yit ꝑper/parde
Whi wil thin harde fader / haıı the spilt
O mercy dere Constable / qd she
As lat my litil child / duelle here with the
And if thow darst not / kepen him for blame
So kisse him onys / in his fadres name
¶ Ther with she loketh bacward / to the londe
And seide farewel housbonde / routheles
And vp she rist / ⁊and walketh doun the stronde
Toward the ship / hir folwith al the pres
And eủer/re she praieth hir child / to holde his pees
And takith hir leve / ⁊and with an holy entente
She blisseth hir / ⁊and in to ship she wente
¶ Vitailled was the ship / it is no drede
Habundauntly for hir / ful longe space
And other necessaries / that sholde nede
She had I now / heried be godis grace
For wynde ⁊and weder / almyghti god purchace
And bringe hir hom / I can no better seye
But in the see / she drivith forth hir weye
Alla the kyng / comth hom sone after this
Vn to his Castel / of the which I tolde
And axeth where his wiff / ⁊and his child is ¶
The Constable gan a boute his herte colde
And pleinle al the mane / to him tolde
As ye haıı herde / I can telle it no better
And shewith the kyng his seal ⁊and his letter
¶ And seide lord as ye commaunded me
Vp peyne of deth so haue I don c̉er/reteyne
This messager turmented was til he
Moost biknowen ⁊and tellen / plat ⁊and pleyne
From night to night / in what place he hath leyne
And thus bi wit / ⁊and subtil enqueryng
Ymagened was / bi whom this harm gan spryng
¶ The honde was knowe / that the lre wroot
And al the venym / of this cursed dede
But in what wise / c̉er/reteinly I noot
The effecte is this / that Alla out of drede
His moder slow / that may men pleynly rede
For that she traitour was / to hir ligeaunce
Thus endith olde Donegild / with meschaunce
¶ The sorow that this Alla / night ⁊and day
Maketh for his wiff / ⁊and for his child also
Ther is no tonge / that it telle may
But now wil I / vn to Custaunce go
That fletith in the see / in peyne ⁊and wo
Fyve yere ⁊and more / as liked cristis sonde
Or that hir ship / approched to the londe
¶ Vnder an hethen Castel / at the laste
Of which the name / in my texte not I fynde
Custaunce ⁊and eke hir̉er/re child / the see vp caste
Almyghti god that saueth / al mankynde
Haue on Custaunce / ⁊and hir child som mynde
That fallen is / in hethen honde efte sone
In poynte to spille / as I wol telle yow sone
¶ Down fro the Castel / comth ther many a wight
To gavren on this ship / ⁊and on Custaunce
But shortly fro the Castel / on a night
The lordis steward / god yeve him meschaunce ¶
A theeff that had renyede oure creaunce
Come in to the ship alone / ⁊and seide he sholde
Hir lemman be / where so she wolde or nolde
¶ Wo was this wrecched woman / tho bigoon
Hir child criede / ⁊and she criede pitously
But blisse ful marie / halp hir right anoon
For with hir strogelyng / wel ⁊and myghtily
The theeff fel oủer/re the bord / al sodeynly
And in the see he dreynte / for vengiaunce
And thus hath crist vnwemmed / kept Custaunce
¶ O foule lust of luxurie / lo thin ende
Not only that thow feyntest / man is mynde
But verryly thow wolt / his body shende
The ende of thi werke / ⁊and of thi lustes blynde
Is compleynyng / how many oon may men fynde
That nought for werke sumtyme / but for thentent
To don this synne / ben eyther sleyne or shent
¶ How may this wayke woman / haıı the strengthe
Hir to defende / ageyne this renegat
O golyas vnmesurable / of lengthe
How myghte Dauid / make the so mat
So yonge / ⁊and of armure / so desolat
How dorst he loke / vppon thi dredful face
Wel may men seen / it was but god is grace
¶ Who yaff Iudith / corage or hardynesse
To slen him Olefernus / in his tent
And to delyủer/ree / out of wrecchednesse
The peple of god / I sey for this entent
That right as god / sprit ⁊and vigor sent
To hem ⁊and saued hem / out of meschaunce
So sent he myght / ⁊and vigour to Custaunce
¶ Forth goth hir ship / thorughout the narwe mouth
Of Iubalter / ⁊and septe drevyng ay
Sumtyme west / ⁊and somtyme North ⁊and south
And sumtyme Est / ful many a wery day
Til cristis moder / that blissed faire may ¶
Hath shapen / thorugh hir endeles goodnesse
To make an ende / of al hir hevynesse
Now late vs stynte of Custaunce / but a throwe
And speke we / of the Romayne Emꝑper/parour
That out of Surrey / hath bi lres knowe
The slaughter of cristen folke / ⁊and dishonour
Don to his doughter / bi a fals traitour
I mene the cursed wikked souldannesse
That at the feste lete slen / both more ⁊and lesse
¶ For which this Emꝑper/parour hath sent anoon
His Senatour / with royal ordynaunce
And other lordis / god woot many oon
On Surreyens to taken / high vengeaunce
Thei brennen slen / ⁊and bryngen hem to meschaunce
Ful many a day / but shortly this is thende
Homward to Rome / thei shapen hem to wende
¶ This Senatour repairith with victorie
To Romeward saillyng / ful royally
And mette the ship / drivyng as seith the storie
In whiche Custaunce sitt / ful pitously
No thing ne knewe he / what she was ne why
She was in suche aray / ne she nyl seye
Of hir estate / though she sholde deye
¶ He bringeth hir to Rome ⁊and to his wiff
He yaff hir / ⁊and hir yonge sone also
And with the Senatour / she lad hir liff
Thus can oure lady / bryngen out of wo
Wooful Custaunce / ⁊and many another mo
And longe tyme / duelled she in that place
In holy workes eủer/re / as was hir grace
¶ The Senatours wiff / hir Aunte was
But for al that / she knewe hir neủer/re the more
I wil no lenger tarien / in this caas
But to kyng Alla / of whiche I spak of yore
That for his wiff wepith / ⁊and siketh sore
I wil retorne / ⁊and lete I wil Custaunce
Vnder the Senatours goủer/renaunce ¶
Kyng Alla / which that had his moder slayne
Vppon a day fil in suche repentaunce
That if I shortly tellen shal ⁊and playne
To Rome comth / to resceive his penaunce
And putt him in the popes ordinaunce
In high ⁊and lowe / ⁊and ihu crist bisoughte
For yeve his wikked workes / that he wroughte
¶ The fame anoon / thorugh Rome town is borne
How Alla kyng / shal comen in pilgremage
Bi herbijours / that wenten him biforne
For which the Senatour / as was vsage
Roode him a yeine / ⁊and many of his lynage
As wel to shewen / his high magnificence
As to don any kyng / a reủer/reence
¶ Grete chere doth this noble Senatour
To kyng Alla / ⁊and he to him also
Eủer/reyche of hem / doth other grete honour
And so bifil / that on a day or two
This Senatour / is to kyng Alla go
To feste / ⁊and shortly if I shal not lye
Custaunces sone / in his companye
¶ Some men wolde seyne / at the request of Custaunce
This Senatour hath lad this child / to feste
I may not tellen / eủer/reyche circumstaunce
Be as be may / there he was at the leste
But soth is this / that at his modres heste
Biforn Alla / duryng the mete space
The child stode / lokyng in the kyngꝭes face
¶ This Alla kyng / hath of the child grete wonder
And to the Senatour / he saide anoon
Whos is that faire child / stondeth yonder
I not qd he bigod / ⁊and bi seint Iohn
A moder he hath / but fader hath he non
That I of woot / ⁊and shortly in a stounde
He tolde Alla / how that this child was founde
¶ But god woot qd this Senatour also
So vertuous aliver in my liff ¶
Ne saw I neủer/ree as she / ne herde of mo
Of worldly women / maide ne of wiff
I dar wel sayn / she had leuer a knyff
Thorughout hir breste / than ben a woman wikke
Ther is noman couth brynge hir / to that prikke
¶ Now was this childe / as lik vn to Custaunce
As possible as is a creature to be
This Alla hath the face / in remembraunce
Of dame Custaunce / ⁊and ther on mused he
If that the childis moder / were aught she
That is his wiff / ⁊and pⁱrivily he sighte
And spedde him fro the table / that he myghte
¶ Perfay thought he / the fantome is in myn hede
I oughte to deme / of rightful Iugement
That in the salt see / my wiff is dede
And afterward he made / his argument
What woot I if that crist / hath heder sent
My wiff bi see / as wel as he hir sente
To my contre / fro thens that she was wente
¶ And after noone / hom with the Senatour
Goth Alla for to seen / this wonder chaunce
This Senatour doth Alla / grete honour
And hastily he sende / after Custaunce
But trusteth wel / she lust nought to daunce
Whan that she wiste / where fore was that sonde
Vnnethe vppon hir feet / she myghte stonde
¶ Whan Alla saw his wiff faire he hir grette
And wepte that it was rewthe for to se
For at the firste look he on hir sette
He knewe wel verrily / that it was she
And for sorowe as dombe stant / as a tre
So was hir herte shette in hir distresse
Whan she remembred his vnkyndenesse
¶ Twies she swowned / in his owne sight
He wepe ⁊and him excuseth / pitously
Now god qd he / ⁊and his halowis bright ¶
So wisly on my soule as haue mercy
That of youre harm as giltles am I
As is Maurice my sone / so lik youre face
Ellis the fende me fecche / out of this place
¶ Longe was the sobbyng / ⁊and the bitter peine
Or that there wooful hertis / myghte ceesse
Grete was the pite / for to hire hem pleyne
Thorugh whiche pleyntes / gan here wo encrese
I pray yow alle / my labour to relesse
I may not tellen here wo / vn til to morowe
I am so wery for to speke of there sorowe
¶ But fynally whan that the soth is wiste
That Alla giltles was / of hir woo
I trowe an C tymes / haıı thei kiste
And suche blisse is there / bitwixe hem two
That saue the ioye / that lasteth eủer/re mo
Ther is noon like / that eny creature
Hath seyne or shal / whiles the world may dure
¶ Tho praide she hir housbond mekely
In relieff of hir longe pitous pyne
That he wolde pray hir fader specially
That of his mageste / he wolde enclyne
To fouch sauff / somday with him todyne
She praide him eke / he sholde bi no weye
Vn to hir fader / no worde of hir seye
¶ Som men wolde sey / how that the child Mauryce
Doth this message / vn to this Emꝑper/parour
But as I gesse / Alla was nought so nyce
To him that was / of so soủer/reeyne honour
As he that is / of cristen folke the flour
Sente any child / but it is bet to deme
He wente him silff / ⁊and so it may wel seme
¶ This Emꝑper/parour / hath graunted gentilly
To come to dyner / as he him bisought
And wel rede I / he lokede besily
Vppon this child / ⁊and on his doughter thought ¶
Alla goth to his In / and as him ought
Arraied for his feste / in eủer/rey wise
As ferforth as his konnyng may suffice
¶ The morowe com / ⁊and Alla gan him dresse
And eke his wiff / this Emꝑper/parour for to mete
And forth thei ride / in ioye ⁊and in gladnesse
And whan she say hir fader / in the strete
She lighte a down / ⁊and fallith him to fete
Fader qd she / youre yonge child Custaunce
Is now ful clene / out of youre remembraunce
¶ I am youre doughter Custaunce / qd she
That whilom ye sente / vn to SurreyeSurryeSurreye
It am I fader / that in the salt see
Was put alone / ⁊and dampned for to dye
Now good fader / mcy I yow crye
Sende me no more / vn to hethenesse
But thonke my lorde here / of his kyndenesse
¶ Who can the pitous ioye / tellen al
Bitwixe hem thre / syn thei ben thus I mette
But of my tale / make an ende I shal
The day goth faste / I wil no lenger̉er/re lette
This glad folke / to dynere thei hem sette
In ioye ⁊and blisse / at mete I lete hem dwelle
A thousand fold wel more / than I can telle
¶ This child Mauryce / was sithen Emꝑper/parour
Made bi the Pope / ⁊and leued cristenly
To cristis chirche / he dide grete honour
But I late al hshishis storie / passen by
Of Custaunce is my tale / specially
In olde Romayne gestis / may men fynde
Mauricis liff / I bere it nought in mynde
¶ This kyng Alla / whan he his tyme say
With his Custaunce / his holy wiff so swete
To Engelond ben thei come / the right way
Where as thei live in ioye / ⁊and in quiete
But litil while it lasteth / I yow hete ¶
Ioye of this world / for tyme wil nought abide
Fro day to night / it chaungeth as the tide
Who leued eủer/ree / in suche delite a day
That he ne meved was / either in conscience
Or ire or talent / or somkyn affray
Envie or pride / or passion or offence
I ne say but for this ende / this sentence
That litil while in ioye / ⁊and in plesaunce
Lasteth the blisse of Alla / with Custaunce
For deth that takith / of highe ⁊and lowe his rente
Whan passed was a yere / even as I gesse
Out of this world / this kyng Alla he hente
For whom Custaunce / hath ful grete hevynesse
Now lat vs prayen god / his soule blesse
And dame Custaunce / fynally to seye
Toward the town of Rome / goth hir weye
To Rome is come / this holy creature
And fyndeth hir frendes / hole ⁊and sounde
Now is she scaped / al hir auenture
And whan she hir fader / hath I founde
Down on hir knees / falleth she to grounde
Wepyng for tendernesse / in herte blithe
She herieth god / an C thousand sithe
In vertu ⁊and holy almesdede
Thei leuen alle / ⁊and neủer/re a sondre wende
Til deth dꝑper/parte hem / this liff thei lede
And fareth now wel / my tale is at an ende
Now ihu crist / that of his myghte may sende
Ioye after wo / goủer/rene vs in his grace
And kepe vs alle / that ben in this place

Here endith the man of lawe his tale And
next folwith the Shipman his prolog

(base) Owre oost vpon his stiropes stood anoon
(base) And seyde goode men herkeneth euerych on
(base) This was a thrifty tale for the nones
(base) Sire parissche prest quod he for goddes boones

(base) Abydeth for goddes digne passioun
(base) For we schal han a predicacioun
(base) Though ye stinte on þis grene her a down
(base) This lollere heere wil prechen vs som what
(base) Nay by my fader soule that schal he nat
(base) Seyde the Esquier heer schal he nat preche
(base) He schal no gospel glosen here ne teche
(base) He leueth all in the grete god he
