(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke
(base) Here endeth the reheytyng of our hoost
(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas

Here endith the Pardoner his ꝓprolog And next
folwy ⁊and nneth his tale
Radix malorum e cupiditas
LOrdynges qd he / in chirche whan I pche
I peyne me to haue / an hauten speche
I rynge it out / as rounde as eny belle
For I roote / that I telle
My tyme is alway oon ⁊and eủer/re was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
First I ꝓpronunce / whens that I come
And than my bulles shewe I alle ⁊and some
Oure liege lordes seal / on my patente
That shewe I first / my body to warente
That no man be so boold / prest ne clerke
Me to distourbe / of cristes holy werke
And aft̉er/re that / telle I forth my tales
Of bulles of popes / ⁊and of Cardynales
Of Patriarkes ⁊and busshoppes / I shewe
And in latyn speke I wordis a fewe
To sauer with my pdicacion
And for to stire men / to deuocion
Than shewe I forth / my longe cristal stones
I crammed ful of cloutes ⁊and of bones
Relikes thei ben / as wene thei echone
Than haue I in laton / a shulder bone ¶
Whiche that was of an holy Iewes shepe
Good men I seie take of my wordes kepe
If that this bon be wasshen in eny welle
Yif Cow or Calff shepe or Oxen swelle
That any worme hath ete / or stonge
Take wat̉er/re of that welle / ⁊and wasshe his tonge
And it is hool anoon / ⁊and ferthermore
Of pokkes ⁊and of scabbes ⁊and of eủer/rey sore
Shal eủer/rey shepe be hool / that of this welle
Drynketh a draughte / take hede what I telle
If that the good man that the best owith
Wol eủer/rey woke ones or the cokke him crowith
Fastyng drinke / of this welle a draughte
As thilke holy Iewe / oure eldres taughte
His bestis ⁊and his stoor / shal multiplie
And sir also / hit helith Ialousie
And though aman be falle / in a Ialou se rage
Lete maken with this wat̉er/re / his potage
And neủer/ree shal he aft̉er/re / his wiff mystriste
Though he the soth of hir defaute wiste
Al had she taken prestis / two or thre
¶ Here is a Meteyne eke / that ye may se
He that his honde wol putte / in this Meteyne
He shal haue multipliyng / of his greyne
Whan he hath sowen be hit whete or Otes
So that ye bringe me gode pans or grotes
Gode men ⁊and women O thing I warne yow
If eny wight be in this chirche now
That hath don synne so horrible that he
Dar nat for shame of it shriven be
Or any woman / be she yonge or oolde
That hath made hir housbonde a Cookeoolde
Suche folke shul haue no power ne no grace
To offre to my relikes in this place
And who so fyndith him out of suche blame
They wol come vp ⁊and offre in godis name ¶
And I assoile him bi the autorite
Which that bi bull I graunted was to me
¶ By this gavde haue I wonne yere bi yere
An hundred marke sithens I was ꝑper/pardonere
I stonde like a prest in the pulpette
And whan the lewed peple / is doun sette
I preche so as ye haue herde bifore
And telle an hundred fals Iapes more .
Than streyne I me to strecche forth my necke
And Est ⁊and west vppon the peple I bekke
As doth a doove / sittyng on a berne
Myn hondes ⁊and my tonge goon ful yerne
That it is Ioye to se my besynesse
Of Auarice / ⁊and of suche cursednesse
Is al my pching / for to make hem fre
To yeve here pans / ⁊and namely vn to me
For myn entent is nat but for to wynne
And nothing for correccion of synne
I recke neủer/re whan thei ben buried
Though that here soules / goon a blakberied
For certes many a pdicacion
Cometh offt tyme / of euel entencion
Some for plesaunce of folke / ⁊and for flaterie
To ben avaunced bi ypocrasie
And some for vayne glorie / ⁊and for hate
For whan I dar / noon other weyes debate
Then wol I stynge hem / with my tonge smerte
In pching so that he shal not a sterte
To ben defamed / falsly if that he
Hath trespassed to my britheren / or to me
For though I telle not / his ꝓpropre name
Men shal wel knowe / that it is the same
Bi som signe / ⁊and other circumstaunces
Thus quyte I folke / that doth vs displesaunces
Thus spute I out my venym / vnder hewe
Of holynesse / to seme holy ⁊and trewe ; ¶
But shortly myn entent I wil devise
I preche for nothing / but for covetise
Therfore my tyme is yit / ⁊and eủer/re was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Thus can I preche ageyne the same vice
Which that I vse / ⁊and that is avarice
But though my silff be gilti in that synne
Yit can I maken other folke / to twynne
From avarice / ⁊and sore hem repente
But that is nat my principal entente
I preche not but for couetise
Of this matire it aught I now suffice
Than telle I hem / ensamples many oon
Of olde stories longe tyme agoon
For lewed peple / louen tales oolde
Suche thinges / conne thei report ⁊and hoolde
What trowe ye whils I may preche
And wynne gold ⁊and siluer for to teche
That I wol lyve in poủer/ret / wilfully
Nay nay I thought it neủer/ree trewely
For I wil preche ⁊and begge in sondry londis
I wol not do no labour with myn hondis
Ne make basketes / ⁊and live ther by
Bicause I wil not beggen ydully
I wol noon of the Appostels contirfete
I wol haue money / malt / Chese ⁊and whete
Al were it yeven / of the porest page
Or of the porest widow in a village
Al shold hir children sterve / or famyne
Nay yit wol I drynke licour of the vyne
And haue a Ioly wenche in eủer/rey toun
But herkeneth lordes my conclusioun
Youre likyng is that I shal telle a tale
Now haue I dronken a draught of corny ale
Bi god I hope I shal telle yow a thinge
That shal bi reson ben at youre likynge ¶
For though my silff be a vicious man
A moral tale yit I yow telle can
Which I am wonte to preche / for to wynne
Now holdith youre pees / my tale I wol bigynne
IN Flaundres whilum was a companye
Of yonge folke that haunted folye
As hazard Riote / stewes / ⁊and tauernes
Harpes Rubibes / lutes ⁊and giternes
Thei daunce ⁊and pley at dys / night ⁊and day
And eten ⁊and drynke more than here might may
Thorugh which thei don the deuel sacrifice
Withinne the deuelis temple / in cursed wise
By suꝑper/parfluite / abhominable
Here Othes ben so grete / ⁊and so dampnable
That it is grysly / to hire hem swere
Oure blissed lordis body thei al to tere
Hem thought Iewes rent him nat I nough
And eche of hem at otheris synne lough
And right anoon come in than Tomblisters
Fetes ⁊and smal ⁊and yonge frutres
Syngers with harpes baudes with wafferers
Which ben verry deuelis officers
To kyndle ⁊and blowe / the fire of lecherie
That is annexed / vn to high glotenye
The holy writte take I to my witnesse
That lecherie is in wyne / ⁊and dronkenesse
Loo how dronken Looth / vnkyndely
Lay bi his doughtres two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he nyst what he wrought
Herodes who so hath the stories sought
Whan of wyne was replete at his feste
Right at his owne table yaff his heeste
To slen the Baptist Iohn ful giltles
Senec seith a good worde douteles
He seith he can no difference fynde
Bitwix a man that is out of his mynde ¶
And a man which that is dronkelewe
But that woodnesse fallen in a shrewe
Perseuerith lenger than doth dronkenesse
O thow gloteny ful of cursednesse
O causer of al oure conficion
Original of oure first dampnacion
Til crist had bought vs with his blood ageyne
Lo how dere shortly for to seyne
I bought was thilke cursed vilonye
Corrupt was al this world / thorugh glotenye
¶ Adam oure fader / ⁊and his wiff also
Fro Paradise / to labour / ⁊and to wo
Were driven for that vice / it is no drede
For whils that Adam fasted / as I rede
He was in Paradise / ⁊and whan that he
Ete of the fruyte / defended on a tre
Anoon he was out caste / to wo ⁊and peyne
O glotenye wel ought vs / on the pleyne
¶ O wiste aman how many maladies
Folwith of excesse / ⁊and of glotenyes
He wold ben the more mesurable
Of his diete sittyng at his table
Allas the shorte throte / the tendre mouthe
Makith that est ⁊and west / Northe ⁊and southe
In erthe in eyre in water man swynke
To geten a gloton / deynte mete ⁊and drynke
Of this matire O Poule wel canst thou trete
Mete vn to wombe wombe eke vn to mete
Shal god distroyen both as Paule vs seith
Allas a foule thing it is / bi my feith
To say this worde ⁊and fouler is the dede
Whan man so drynketh of the white ⁊and rede
That of his throte he makith his privite
Thorugh that high cursed suꝑper/parfluyte
The Appostel weping / seith ful petously
Ther walken many / of which told haue I ¶
I seie it now weping with a pitous voice
Ther ben enemyes of cristis croice
Of whiche the ende is deth for wombe is here god
O wombe O baly O foule stinking cod
Fulfilled of donge ⁊and of corrupcione
At either ende of the / foule is the sowne
How grete cost ⁊and labour is hit to fynde
These cokes how thei stampe streyne ⁊and grynde
And turne substaunce in to accidente
To fulfille al thi likerous talente
Out of the harde bones / knokke they
The mary for thei cast it not awey
That may go thorugh the golet soffte ⁊and soote
Of spicerie of leves / barke ⁊and roote
Shal ben his savse I made bi delite
To maken him yit a newe appetite
But certis he that haunteth suche delices
Is deed whils that he levith in tho vices
A lecherous thing is wyne / ⁊and dronkenesse
It is ful of strivyng / ⁊and of wrecchidnesse
O dronken man / al disfigured is thi face
Sowre is thi breeth foule artow to enbrace
And thorugh thi dronken nose / sowneth thi soun
As though thou seidist ay Sampson Sampsoun
And yit god woot Sampson dronke neủer/re wyne
Thou fallest as it were / a dronken swyne
Thi tonge is lost ⁊and al thin honest cure
For dronkenesse is verray sepulture
Of man is witt ⁊and his discrecion
In whom that drynke hath dıı̄unacion
He can no counsail kepe it is no drede
Now kepe yow fro the white / ⁊and fro the rede
And namely fro the white wyne of lepe
That is to selle in fissh strete / ⁊and in Chepe
This wyne of Spayne crepith subtilly
In other wynes / growyng faste by ¶
Of which ther risith suche fumosite
That whan aman hath dronke draughtes two or thre
And wenyth that he be at home in Chepe
Than is he in Spayne / at the toun of Lepe
Not at the Rochel / ne at Burdieux toun
Than wol thei seie / Sampson Sampsoun
But herkeneth lordinges I yow pray
That alle the soủer/reayne actes / dar I say
Of victories in the oolde testament
That thorugh verray god / that is omnipotent
Were don in abstinence ⁊and in prayere
Loketh the bible / ⁊and there ye may it lere
Loke Attilla the grete conquerour
Deide in his slepe / with shame ⁊and dishonour
Bleding at his nose in dronkennesse
A Capitayne shuld live / in soburnesse
And oủer/re al this avisith yow right wel
What was commaunded / vn to Lamuel
Not Samuel / but Lamuel seie I
Redith the bible / ⁊and fyndith it expressely
Of wyne yevyng / to hem that haue Iustice
No more of this for it may wel suffice
And now that I haue speken of glotenye
Now wol I defende yow hasardie
Hasarde is verray moder of lesinges
And of disceite ⁊and cursed forsweringes
Blaspheme of crist manslaught̉er/re ⁊and wast also
Of catel ⁊and of tyme ⁊and ferthermo
Hit is repreff / ⁊and contrarie to honour
For to ben holden a comune hasardour
And eủer/re the highere he is of estate
The more is he holden disolate
If that a ꝓprorince vse hasardie
In al goủer/renaunce ⁊and policie
He is as bi comune oppinion
Holde the lasse / in reputacion ¶
that was holde awise enbassiatour
Was sente in to with ful grete honour
Fro Lacedomye / to make hire aliaunce
And whan he cam happed this chaunce
That al the grettest / that were of that londe
Pleying at the hasard he hem fonde
For whiche as sone / as hit myghte be
He stale him home ayen / to his contre
And seide there wil I not lese my name
I wol not take on me / so grete diffame
For to allye yow / to noon hasardoures
Sendith other wiser Enbassiatous
For bi my trouth / me were leủer/ree die
Than I shuld yow / to hasardours alie
For ye that ben so glorious in honomres
Shal not allie yow / with hasardoures
As by my wil / ne as bi my trete
This wise Philosᵒphre / thus seide he
¶ Loke eke that to the kyng Demetryus
The kyng of Partes / as the booke seith vs
Sente him a peire of dies of gold / in skorne
For he had vsed hasardie / there biforne
For whiche he helde his glorie / ⁊and his renoun
At no valowe / of eny reputacioun
Lordis may fynde / other mane pley
Honest I now / to drive the day a wey
Now wol I speke of othes / fals ⁊and grete
A worde or two / as olde bookes entrete
Grete sweryng is a thing abhomynable
And fals sweryng / is mech more reꝓprovable
The high god forbad sweryng / at al
Witnesse of Matheu / but in especial
Of sweryng seith the holy Ieromye
Thow shalt swere sooth thin othes / ⁊and not lye
And swere in doome / ⁊and eke in rightwisnesse
But ydel sweryng / is a cursednesse ⁊and¶
Beholde ⁊and se that in the first table
Of high godis hestes most honourable
How that the seconde heste of him / is this
Take not my name in ydelnesse amys
Lo rather he forbedith the sweryng
Than homycide / or many a cursed thing
I seie as bi ordre thus it stondith
This knowe thei / that his hestes vnderstondith
How that the seconde heste of god is that
And ferther oủer/re I wil the telle al plat
That vengeaunce shal not deꝑper/parte / from his hous
That of his othes / is so foule outragious
Bi godis precious herte ⁊and bi his naylis
And bi the blood of crist that is in haylis
Seven is my chaunce ⁊and thin is synke ⁊and treye
Bi godis armes if thou falsly pleye
This dagger shal thorugh thin herte goo
This fruyte cometh of this cursed bones twoo
For sweryng Ire falsnesse ⁊and homycide
Now for the loue of crist / that for vs dide
Leueth youre othes both grete ⁊and smale
For I shal telle yow a merveilous tale
These riatoures thre of which I telle
Long erst or pⁱrime ronge of any belle
Were sette in a taủer/rene for to drynke
And as thei sate they herde a belle clynke
Biforn a corps was caried to his grave
That oon of hem gan calle to him his knave
Goo bet qd he ⁊and aske redily
What corps is this that passeth forth by
And loke that thow repoorte his name wele
Sir qd this boy / it nedith neủer/re a dele
Hit was me tolde er ye cam here two houres
He was ꝑper/parde an olde felawe of youres
Al sodeynly he was slayne this nyght
For dronke as he sat on his benche vpright ¶
Ther cam a previ cheeff men callen deth
That in this contre al the peple sleth
And with his spere he smote his herte a two
And wente his wey withoute wordes mo
He hath a thousand sleyne this pestilence
And maister er ye come in his psence
Me thenketh that it were necessarie
For to be war of suche an adủer/resarie
Beth redy for to mete him eủer/remore
Thus taughte me my dame / I seie nomore
Bi seint Marye seide this Taủer/renere
The childe seith soth for he hath sleyn this yere
Hens oủer/re a myle / withinne a grete vilage
Both man ⁊and woman hyne child ⁊and page
I trow that his habitacion be there
To be wel avised grete wisedome it were
Or that he do aman adishonoure
Ye godis armes qd this riatoure
Is it suche ꝑper/parel with him for to mete
I shal him seke bi dale ⁊and bi strete
I make a vow bi godis digne bones
Herkenth felowes we thre thre ben al ones
Lete eche of vs hold vp his honde to other
And eche of vs bi come otheris brother
And we wol sle this fals traitour deth
He shal be sleyne that so many sleth
Bi godis dignite er hit be nyght
To gedre han these thre here trouthes plight
To live ⁊and die eche of hem with other
As thowgh he were his owne born brother
And vp thei sterten / al dronken in this rage
And forth thei goon toward that vilage
Of whiche the Taủer/renere spake biforn
And many a grisly othe than han thei sworn
And cristes blissed body they to rente
That deth shal be deed if thei may him hente . ¶
Whan thei had goon not fully a myle
Right as thei wolden haue troden oủer/re a stile
An olde pore man with hem mette
This olde man ful mekely hem grette
And seide thus now lordes god yow se
The proudest of these riatoures thre
Answerd ageyne what cherle with harde grace
Whi artow al forwrapped / saue thi face
Whi livest thou so longe / in so grete age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And seide thus for I can not fynde
A man though that I walked in to Inde
Neither in Cite ne in no mane vilage
That wil changen his youth for myn age
And therfore moty haue myn age stille
As longe tyme as it is godis wille
Ne deth allas ne wol not haue my liff
Thus walke I I like a recheles caytiff
And on the grounde which is my moder gate
I knoke with my staff both erly ⁊and late
And seye leve moder lete me inne
Lo how I wanyssh flessh blood ⁊and skynne
Allas whan shul my bones ben at reste
Moder with yow wolde I change my cheste
That in my chambre longe tyme hath be
Ye for an heyre cloutte to wrappe in me
But yit to me she wil not do that grace
For which ful pale ⁊and welkid is my face
¶ But sirs to yow it is no curtesie
To speken to an oolde man vilonye
But he trespace in worde / or ellis in dede
In holy write ye may your silff wel rede
Ayenst an olde man hoor vppon his hede
Ye shul arise therfore I yeve yow rede
Ne doth to an olde man harme as now
No more than ye wolde a man dede yow ¶
In age if ye so longe may abide
And god be with yow / where so ye go or ride
I most go theder as I haue to goo
Nay olde cherle bi god / thou shalt nat soo
Seide this other hasardour anoon
Thou ꝑper/partist nat so lightly bi seint Iohn
Thou spake right now / of thilke traitour deeth
That in this contre alle oure frendes sleeth .
Haue here my trouthe thow art his aspie
Telle where he is or ellis thow shalt die
Bi god ⁊and bi the holy sacramente
Ful truly thow art oon of his assente
To slen vs yonge folke / thow fals theeff
Now sirs if it be to yow so leeff
To fynde deth turne vp this croked wey
For in that grove I lefft him bi my fey
Vnder a tre ⁊and there he wol abide
Ne for youre boost he nyl him nothing hide .
Se ye that ooke right there ye shul him fynde
God save yow that boughte ayen mankynde
And yow amende thus seide this olde man
And eủer/reeche of these riatours fast ran
Til thei come to the tre / ⁊and there thei founde
Floreyns of fyne gold / I koyned rounde
Wel nygh an seven busshels / as hem thoughte
No lenger than after deeth / thei ne soughte
But eche of hem so glad was of that sight
For the floreyns / were so feire ⁊and bright
That doun thei sette hem / bi this pcious horde
The worst of hem / he spake the first worde
Brithren qd he take kepe what I seie
My witte is grete though that I borde ⁊and pleye
This tresoure hath fortune to vs yeven
In merthe ⁊and iolyte / oure liff to liven
And lightly as it cometh so wil we spende
Ey godis pcious herte who wende . ¶ꝑper/par
Today that we shulde haue had so feire a grace
But myghte this gold be caried fro this place
Home to myn hous or ellis vn to youres
For wel I woot that al this golde is oures
Than were we / in high felicite
But truly bi day hit may nat be
Men wolde seie / that we were thevis stronge
And for oure owne tresoure / don vs honge
This tresoure mot be caried bi nyghte
As wisely ⁊and as slighly / as we myghte
Wherfore I rede / that Cutt amonges vs alle
We drawe / ⁊and lete se where the Cutt wol falle
And he that hath the Cutt with herte blithe
Shal renne to toune / ⁊and that ful swithe
To bringe vs brede ⁊and wyne / ful pⁱrivily
And two of vs shul kepen / ful subtilly
This tresoure wel / ⁊and if he wol nat tarie
Whan it is night / we wil this tresoure carie
Bi oon assente where as vs likith beste liste
That oon of hem / the cutt brought in his fiste
And bade hem drawe / ⁊and loke where it wol falle
And it fel on the yongest / of hem alle
And forth toward the toune / he wente anoon
And also sone as he was agoon
That oon of hem spake / vn to that other
Thou knowest wel / thou art my sworn brother
Thi profite wol I telle the anoon
Thou wost wel / that oure felawe is goon
And here is gold / ⁊and that ful grete plente
That shuld I ꝑper/parted be among vs thre
But natheles if I con the shap hit so
That hit deꝑper/parted were among vs two
Had I nat don / a frendes turne to the
That other answerde / I note how that myghte be
I wolde wel that the gold / were oures two
What shulde we do that it myghte be so . ¶
Shal hit be counsaille / seide the first shrewe
And I shal tellen it / in wordes fewe
What we shul don / ⁊and bringe it wel aboughte
I graunte qd that other / out of doute .
That bi my trouth / I wil the not biwreyene
Now qd the first / thou wost wel we ben tweyne
And two of vs / shul strenger be than oon
Loke whan he is sette / ⁊and that anoon
Arise as though thou woldest / with him pleye
And I shal rive him / thorugh his sides tweye
Whils that thou strogelest with him / as in game
And with thi dagger / loke thou do the same
And than shal al this gold / deꝑper/parted be
My dere frende / bi twix the ⁊and me
Than may we booth / oure lustes fulfille

endith the Maunciple his tale . And
yng the ꝑper/parson seith his Prologus
x that the Maunciple / had his tale endede
sonne fro the southe side / is descendede
we / that he waswas nat / to my sight
Degreis as of hight
Ten of the clokke / hit was tho as I gesse
For euleven foote / litil more or lesse
My shadowe was / at thilke tyme as there
Of suche feete / as my lengthe ꝑper/parted were
In six foote equale / bi even ꝓproporcion
Therwith the Mones exaltacion ¶ꝑper/par
I mene Libra / alwey gan ascende
As we were entrynge / at the Thropes ende
For whiche oure Oste / as he was wonte to guye
As in this caas / oure ioly companye
Seide in this wise / lordinges eủer/reychoon
Now lacketh vs no tale mo / than oon
Fulfilled is my sentence / ⁊and my decre
I trowe that we han herde / of eche degre
Al most fulfilled is / myn ordenaunce
I pray to god / so yeve him right good chaunce
That tellith this tale / to vs lustily
¶ Sir prest qd he / art thow a vicary
Or art thow a ꝐPer/Parson / seie soth bi thi feye
Be what thow be / breke nat oure pleye
For eủer/rey man saue thow / hath tolde his tale
Vnbocle ⁊and shewe vs / what is in thi male
For truly me thenketh / bi thi chere
Thow sholdist knytt vp wel / agrete matere
Telle vs som fable / for cokkes bones
This ꝑper/parsoıı̄un answerde / al at ones
Thow getest fable noon / I tolde for me
For Paule that writeth / vn to Timothe
Reprevith hem / that weyven sothfastnesse
And tellen fables / ⁊and suche cursednesse
Whi sholde I sowen draff / out of my fist
Whan I may sowe whete / if that me list
For whiche I seie / if yow list to here
Moralite / ⁊and right vertuous matere
And than that ye wol / yeue me audience
I wol ful fayne / at cristes reủer/reence
Don yow plesaunce lefful / as I can
But trusteth wel / I am a sothern man
I can not geste / Rom Ram Ruff / bi letter
Ne god woote / Ryme holde I / but litel better
And therfore if yow luste / I wol nat glose
I wol yow telle / a mery tale in prose . ¶
To knytt vp al this feste / ⁊and make an ende
And Ihu for his grace / witt me sende
To shewe yow the wey / in this viage
Of thilke ꝑper/parfite ⁊and glorious / pilgremage .
That hight Ierusalem / celestial
And if ye vouchesaf / anoon I shal
Bigynne vppon my tale / for which I pray
Telle youre avise / I can no bett̉er/re say
But natheles / this meditacion
I put it ay / vnder the correccion
Of clerkes / for I am nat textuel
I take but the sentence / trusteth wel
Therfore I make / a protestacion
That I wol stonde / to correccion
Vppon this worde / we han assented soone
For as hit semed / hit was for to doone
To enden / in som v̉er/retuous sentence
And for to yeve him space / ⁊and audience
And bad oure Oste / he shulde to him say
That alle we / to telle his tale him pray
Oure Oste had the wordes / for vs alle
Sir prest qd he / now faire yow befalle
Sey what yow luste / ⁊and we wol gladly here
And with that worde / he seide in this manere
Telleth qd he / youre meditacioun
But hasteth yow / the sonne wol a doun
Beth fructuous / ⁊and that in litel space
And to do wel / god sende yow his grace .

Here endith the ꝑper/parson his prolog And
next folowyng bigynneth his tale .

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth the Persons tale

(base) Iere 6ᵒ State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

wey

of glorie

(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

(base) and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence

(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

(base) and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle

(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and
no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym
oghte repente

(base) wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne
may nat auaile

(base) But nathelees men shal hope that at euery
tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly

it is greet dowithe

(base) for
as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne

(base) and ther fore
repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that
synne forlete hem holy chirche halt hem siker of hire sauacion

(base) and he that synneth and verraily repenteth hym in his laste
holy chirche yet hopeth his sauacioun by the grete mercy of oure
lord Ihesu crist for his repentance but taak the siker wey

(base) and
Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence
Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

(base) Seint
Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may
nat bigynne the newe clene lyf

(base) for certes if he be baptised with
oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

(base) Another defaute is this that men doon
deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

(base) The

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of

(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as

(base) Another is whan man hath synned

(base) Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen

(base) Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men

(base) Now

shaltow vnderstande

this stant on iij thynges

(base) Contricioun of herte Confessioun of
Mouth and Satisfaccioun

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus
Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym

thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree
